div2.entryFree:
alphabetical letter t t
The third letter of the alphabet: called taA='N and taA [respecting which latter see the letter b]: the pl. [of the former is taA='aAtN; and of the latter,] A^atowaA='u. (TA in bAb AlAlf Allyin~p.) It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice], and of those termed niTaEiy~ap [and niToEiy~ap and naTaEiy~ap and naToEiy~ap pronounced by pressing the tip of the tongue against the upper gums and suddenly withdrawing it with an emission of the breath]: these latter are T and d and t, three letters that are among those which are changed into other letters. (TA at the commencement of bAb AltA='.) -A2- It is one of the augmentative letters: (S:) and is movent when added at the beginning of a noun, and at the end of a noun, [and at the beginning of a verb,] and at the end of a verb, and is also quiescent at the end of a verb. (Mughnee, K.) -A3- Added at the beginning of a noun, it is a preposition, or particle governing the gen. case, significant of swearing, (S, * Mughnee, K,) and denoting wonder; (Mughnee, K;) and [accord. to general usage] it is peculiarly prefixed to the name All~`h; (S, Mughnee, K;) as in taA@ll~`hi laqado kaAna ka*aA [By God, verily it was thus, or verily such a thing was]; (S;) and taA@ll~`hi laA^afoEalan~a ka*aA [By God, I will assuredly do such a thing]: (TA:) but sometimes they said, tarab~iY [By my Lord], and tarab~i AlkaEobapi [By the Lord of the Kaabeh], and taA@lr~aHomaAni [By the Compassionate], (Mughnee, K,) as is related on the authority of Akh; deviating from common usage. (TA.) Thus used, it is a substitute for w, (S, Mughnee,) as it is also in tatoraY and turaAvN and tujaAha and tuxamapN [&c.]; (S;) and the w is a substitute for b; (S, Mughnee;) but the t has the additional meaning of denoting wonder: so says Z. (Mughnee.) -A4- Added at the end of a noun, it is a particle of allocution: (Mughnee, K:) it is thus added in A^anota [Thou], (S, Mughnee, K,) addressed to a male, (TA,) and A^anoti [Thou], (Mughnee, K,) addressed to a female; (TA;) uniting with the noun, as though the two became one; not being an affixed noun governed in the gen. case. (S. [See A^ano.]) -A5- It is added in [the beginning of] the second person of the future, (S,) [i. e.,] in the beginning of the aor., (TA,) [as a particle of allocution,] as in A^anota tafoEalu [Thou dost, or wilt do]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- It is also added, as a sign of the fem. gender, in the beginning of the future, [or aor.,] as in hiYa tafoEalu [She does, or will do]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- It is also added in the beginning of the third person [fem.] of the [aor. used as an] imperative, [as a sign of the fem. gender,] as in litaqumo hinodu [Let Hind stand]. (TA.) ― -b4- And sometimes it is added in the beginning of the second person of the [aor. used as an] imperative, [as a particle of allocution,] as in the phrase in the Kur [x. 59, accord. to one reading], fabi*`lika falotaforaHuwA [Therefore therein rejoice ye]: and in the saying of the rájiz,
tiy^o*ano faA_in~iY Hamow^uhaA wajaAruhaA
qulotu libaw~aAbK ladayohi daAruhaA
[explained in art.A*n]: and [thus] it is added in the beginning of [the second person of] the [aor. used as an] imperative of a verb of which the agent is not named, as in lituzoha yaA rajulu [Be thou proud, vain, boastful, or self-conceited, O man], from zuhiYa: but Akh says that the adding of the l in the beginning of the second person of the [aor. used as an] imperative [except in the case of a pass. verb or a verb of which the agent is not named] is a bad idiom, because the l is not needed. (S, TA.) -A6- The movent t added at the end of a verb is a pronoun, as in qumotu [I stood], (Mughnee, K,) and qumota [Thou stoodest, addressed to a male], and qumoti [Thou stoodest, addressed to a female]: (Mughnee:) thus added in the first and second persons of the pret., it is a pronoun denoting the agent. (S.) ― -b2- The quiescent t added at the end of a verb is a sign of the fem. gender, (Mughnee, K,) i. e., a particle applied to denote the fem. gender, (Mughnee,) as in qaAmato [She stood]. (Mughnee, K.) J says [in the S] that, when thus added at the end of the pret., it is a pronoun: but IB says [correctly] that it is a particle. (TA.) -A7- It is also, sometimes, affixed to vum~a and rub~a; and in these cases it is most commonly movent with fet-h, (Mughnee, K,) so that one says vum~ata and rub~ata. (TA.) [See arts. vm and rb.] -A8- ti is an imperative of A^ataY. (M in art. AtY.) -A9- [As a numeral, t denotes Four hundred.]

taA tA fem. of *aA; (M;) i. q. *iho [This and that]; (T;) a noun of indication, denoting that which is female or feminine; like *aA (S, K) applied to that which is male or masculine; (S;) and you say also tiho, like *iho: (S, K:) the dual is taAni: and the pl., A^uwlaA='i. (S, K.) En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee] says, (T, S,) excusing himself to En-Noamán [Aboo-Káboos], whom he had satirized, (TA,)
haA A_in~a taA Ei*orapN A_ino lamo takuno nafaEato
faA_in~a SaAHibahaA qado taAha fiY Albaladi
[Now verily this is an excuse: if it profit not, then verily its author has lost his way in the desert, or in the waterless desert]: (T, S: but in the latter, lA is put in the place of lm:) tA here points to the qaSiydap [or ode]; and E*rp is a subst from AiEoti*aArN; and tAh means taHay~ara; and Albld means AlmafaAzap. (TA.) The dim. of taA is tay~aA, (T, S, M, K,) which is anomalous, like *ay~aA the dim. of *aA, &c. (I'Ak p. 343. [Much has been written respecting the formation of this dim. to reduce it to something like rule, but I pass it over as, in my opinion, unprofitable and unsatisfactory; and only refer to what is said respecting the duals A^ulay~aA and A^ulay~aA='i in art. AlY. See an ex. voce mir~apN.] ― -b2- haA is prefixed to it (T, S, K) [as an inceptive particle] to give notice of what is about to be said, (S,) so that one says haAtaA [meaning This], (T, S, K,) as in haAtaA fulaAnapu [This is such a woman]; (T;) and [in the dual] haAtaAni; and [in the pl.] h`w^ulaA='i: and the dim. is haAtay~aA. (S.) ― -b3- When you use it in addressing another person, you add to it k [as a particle of allocution], and say taAka (S, K) and tiyka and tiloka (T, S, K) and taloka, which is a bad dial. var., (S, K,) and taAlika, (T, S,) which is the worst of these: (T:) [all meaning That:] the dual is taAnika and taAn~ika, the latter with tesh-deed, (S, K, [but in some copies of the S, only the latter is mentioned,]) and taAlika [which, like taAn~ika, is dual of tiloka or taloka, which are contractions of taAlika; these two duals being for taAnilika, the original, but unused, form]: (K:) the pl. is A^uwl`y^ika [or A^uwlaA=y^ika] and A^uwlaAka and A^uwlaAlika [respecting all of which see A^ulaY, in art. AlY]: (S, K:) and the dim. is tay~aAka and tay~aAlika: (K: [in the TA, the latter is erroneously written tay~Anika:]) the k relates to the person or persons whom you address, masc. and fem. and dual and pl.: [but in addressing a female, you may say taAki &c.; in addressing two persons, taAkumaA &c.; in addressing more than two males, taAkumo &c.; and in addressing more than two females, taAkun~a &c.:] what precedes the k relates to the person [or thing] indicated, masc. and fem. and dual and pl. (S.) ― -b4- haA is also prefixed to tiyka and taAka, so that one says, haAtiyka hinodu and haAtaAka hinodu [This, or that, is Hind]. (S, K. *) Abu-n-Nejm says,
jiy^onaA nuHay~iyka wanasotajodiykaA
faA@foEalo binaA haAtaAka A^awo haAtiykaA
meaning [We have come saluting thee and seeking of thee a gift: then do thou to us] this or that: [give us] a salutation or a gift. (S.) The haA that is used to give notice of what is about to be said is not prefixed to tlk because the l is made a substitute for that hA: (S, TA:) or, as IB says, they do not prefix that hA to *`lika and tiloka because the l denotes the remoteness of that which is indicated and the hA denotes its nearness, so that
the two are incompatible. (TA.) -A2- taA and tA='N Names of the letter t: see that letter, and see arts. twA^ and tY. -A3- taA and taA^aA or taA= for ta$aA=': see (near its end) art. A.

R. Q. 1 taA^otaA^a * , inf. n. tA^otaA^apN, He reiterated the letter t in speaking. (S, K.) ― -b2- taA^otaA^a biAlt~ayosi, (T, M,) inf. n. as above (T, M, K) and tiy^otaA='N, (M,) or taA^otaA='N, (K,) He called the he-goat to copulate, (T, M, K,) or to approach, (M,) saying ↓ taA^o taA^o. (M.)
taA^o taA^o * : see what next precedes.

taA^otaA^apN *
An onomatopœia [imitative of the sound made in reiterating the letter t in speaking: or, in calling a he-goat to copulate, or to approach: see the verb, above]. (T, K.)
taA^otaA='N * A man who reiterates the letter t in speaking. (S, K. *)

4 A^atoA^arotu A_ilayohi Aln~aZara *
I continued to look at him time after time (taArapF baEoda taArapK): (T, TA:) or I looked at him sharply, or intently. (Fr, T, M, K.) And A^atoA^arotuhu baSariY, (T, S, M, K,) and A^atoA^arotu A_ilayohi AlbaSara, (K,) I followed him with my eye; made my eye to follow him. (S, M, K.) [See also art. twr.]
taArapN tArh tArp , without ' on account of frequent usage, (IAar, T, Msb in art. twr, and K,) A time; one time; [in the sense of the French fois;] syn.

mar~apN mr mrh mrp : (Msb, K:) or a time, whether long or short; syn. HiynN: (IAar:) sometimes, however, it is pronounced taA^orapN: (Msb:) pl. tiy^arN (T, Msb, K) and tiy^aArN: (Msb:) these are pls. of taA^orapN; but the pl. of taArapN without ' is taAraAtN (Msb) and tiyarN (S in art. tyr, and K and K in art. twr,) and tiyaArN. (S in art. tyr.) [See also art. twr.]

mutaArN mtAr in the saying
faSirotu kaA^an~aniY faraA^N mutaAru
is [said by ISd to be] for mutoA^arN [pass. part. n. of A^atoA^ara; so that the meaning is, And I became as though I were a wild ass looked at sharply or intently, or followed by the eye, in order to be captured or shot]. (M, TA. [But see art. twr.])

3 taA='ama A^axaAhu * , (K, TA, [in the TT, as from the M, written taA^ama, and so by Golius,]) inf. n. mutaA='amapN, (TA,) He was twinborn with his brother. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- tA='m, (S,) or tA='m vawobFA, (M, K, TA, [in the TT, again, written taA^ama,]) inf. n. as above, (S, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He wove a piece of cloth of threads two and two together (S, M, K) in its warp and its woof. (K.) [See mitoA=mN, and see also niyrN.] ― -b3- tA='m Alfarasu, (K, [written by Golius taA^ama,]) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The horse fetched run after run. (K.)

4 A^atoA^amato *
She (a mother, K, or a woman, S, M, Msb, and any pregnant animal, M) twinned, or brought forth two at one birth. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) -A2- A^atoA^amahaA i. q. A^afoDaAhaA [like A=tamahaA, q. v. in art. Atm]. (S, K.) [Golius and Freytag have rendered it as though it meant A^afoDaY A_ilayohaA.]
tiy^omN * , whence huwa tiy^omuhu: see tawo'amN.
tay^iymN * , whence huwa tay^iymuhu: see tawo'amN.

tuw^aAmiy~apN *
A pearl; (M, K;) so called in relation to tuw^aAmN, (TA,) which is a town twenty leagues from the metropolis of 'Omán, (K, TA,) in the tract next the sea, (TA,) a city of 'Omán whence pearls are purchased, (M,) erroneously called by J tawo'amN, [but in one copy of the S I find it written tuwAm,] and said by him to be the metropolis of 'Omán; (K;) as also ↓ tawo'amiy~apN, (TA, [and thus it is written in copies of the S, but in one copy I find it written tuwAmiy~ap,]) thought by En-Nejeeremee to be thus called in relation to the oyster-shell, because this is always what is termed tawo'amN, q. v. (TA.)

tawo'amN tm tw'm twA^m
A twin; one of two young, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and of more, (M, K,) brought forth at one birth, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) of any animals; whether a male or a female, or a male [brought forth] with a female; (M, K;) and tawo'amapN is [also] applied to a female: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) it occurs in poetry contracted into tawamN: (M:) the pl. is tawaAy^imu and tuw^aAmN, (S, M, Msb, K,) the latter of which is of a rare form, not without parallels, (M,) said by some to be a quasi-pl. n., and by some to be originally [tiy^aAmN,] with kesr, but the assertion of these last is condemned by AHei; (MF;) and tawo'amuwna is allowable as applied to human beings: (S, TA:) you say, huwa tawo'amuhu [in the TA, erroneously, tuw^omuhu, with damm,] and ↓ tiy^omuhu and ↓ tay^iymuhu [in the CK tayoy^muhu] (AZ, M, K) [meaning He is his twin-brother]: and humaA tawo'amaAni (S, * M, Mgh, Msb * K) and tawo'amN (M, K) [They two are twin-brothers]: or tawo'amN applies only to one of the two; (Msb;) it is a mistake to say humaA tawo'amN and humaA zawojN: (Mgh:) [but see zawojN:] Lth says that tawo'amN applies to two sons, or young ones, [born] together; and that one should not say humaA tawo'amaAni, but humaA tawo'amN: this, however, is a mistake: correctly, as ISk and Fr say, tawo'amN applies to one, and tawo'amaAni to two. (T, TA.) It is of the measure fawoEalN, (Kh, S, IB, Msb,) in the opinion of some, (IB,) and originally wawo'amN, (Kh, T, S, IB,) like as tawolajN is originally wawolajN; (Kh, T, S;) from Alwiy^aAmu, (T, IB,) “ the being mutually near, ” (T,) “ mutually agreeing, ” (T, IB,) “ being mutually conformable; ” (IB;) so that it means one that agrees with, or matches, another, (IB.) ― -b2- It is metaphorically used in relation to all things resembling one another [so that it means (tropical:) One of a pair]. (M.) A poet says,
qaAlato lanaA wadamoEuhaA tuw^aAmu
kaA@ld~ur~i A_i*o A^asolamahu A@ln~iZaAmu
EalaY A@l~a*iyna A@rotaHaluwA A@ls~alaAmu
(assumed tropical:) [She said to us, while her tears fell in pairs, or in close succession, like large pearls when the string lets them drop off, Upon those who have departed be peace]. (S.) [This citation, and what immediately follows it in the S, mentioning the pl. tawo'amuwna, not tuw^aAmuwna, have been misunderstood by Golius; and Freytag has followed him in this case.] ― -b3- Alt~awo'amu is also [a name of] (assumed tropical:) A certain Mansion [of the Moon; namely, the Sixth; more commonly called AlhanoEapu;] pertaining to AljawozaA=' [here meaning Gemini]; (M, K;) one of two [asterisms] called tawo'amaAni: (M:) Alt~awo'amaAni is (assumed tropical:) The Sign of Gemini. (Kzw.) ― -b4- [The pl.] tawaAy^imu also signifies (assumed tropical:) Clusters, or what are clustered together, (maA ta$aAbaka,) of stars, and of pearls. (M, K.) ― -b5- And tawo'amaAni, (assumed tropical:) A pair of pearls, or large pearls, for the ear: each of them is termed a tawo'amap to the other. (TA.) ― -b6- Alt~awo'amaAni, [in the CK Alt~awo'amAnu,] (assumed tropical:) A certain small herb, (AHn, M, K,) having a fruit like cumin-seed, (AHn, M, and K in art. wA^m,) and many leaves, growing in the plains, spreading long and wide, and having a yellow flower. (AHn, TA.) ― -b7- Alt~awo'amu also signifies (assumed tropical:) The arrow of the kind used in the game called Almayosir: (M:) or a certain arrow of those used in that game: (K:) or the second of those arrows; (S, M, K;) said by Lh to have two notches, and to entitle to two portions [of the slaughtered camel] if successful, and to subject to the payment for two portions if unsuccessful. (M.) ― -b8- And tawo'amaAtN, (assumed tropical:) A kind of women's vehicles [borne by camels], (T, K,) like the ma$aAjir, (T, TA,) erroneously said in the copies of the K to be like the ma$aAjib, (TA,) having no coverings, or canopies: the sing. is tawo'amapN. (T, K.)
tawo'amiy~apN tmyh tmyp tw'myh tw'myp twA^m : see tuw^aAmiy~apN.

mutoy^imN *
Twinning, or bringing forth two at one birth; (S, M, Msb, K;) applied to a mother, (K,) or a woman, (S, M, Msb,) and to any pregnant animal; (M;) without p. (Msb.)

mitoA=mN mtA=m
Accustomed to twin, or bring forth two at one birth; (S, M, K;) applied to a mother, (K,) or a woman, (S, M,) and to any pregnant animal: (M:) pl. mataAy^iymu. (Har p. 613.) ― -b2- Hence, (Har ubi suprà,) vawobN mitoA=mN, (S, Har,) or ↓ mutaA='amN, (TA, PS,) [both app. correct,] (assumed tropical:) A piece of cloth woven of threads two and two together in its warp and its woof. (S, Har, TA.) ― -b3- Hence, also, A^aboyaAtN mataAy^iymu (tropical:) Verses consisting of words in pairs whereof each member resembles the other in writing. (Har ubi suprà.) [See also mutawo'amN.]
mutaA='amN mtA='m : see mitoA=mN.
farasN mutaAy^imN * (assumed tropical:) A horse fetching, or that fetches, run after run. (S, M.)

tajoniysN mutawo'amN tjnys mtm tjnys mtw'm (assumed tropical:) The using two words resembling each other in writing but not in expression; as
in the saying, gar~aka Eiz~uka faSaAra quSaAru *`lika *ul~aka faA@xo$a faAHi$a fiEolika faEal~aka tuhodaA bih`*aA [Thy might, or elevated rank, hath deceived thee, and the end of that has become thine ignominy: fear then thine exorbitant deed, and may-be thou wilt be made to follow a right course by this]. (Har p. 269.)

1 tabV3a [tab~a, aor.
tabi3a , inf. n. tab~N, and perhaps ↓ tababN and ↓ tabaAbN and ↓ tabiybN, He, or it, suffered loss, or diminution; or became lost: and perished, or died: as also ↓ tb~b, inf. n. tatobiybN: and app. tub~a also.] tab~N (M, A, K) and ↓ tatobiybN (M, K) [as inf. ns.] signify The suffering loss, or diminution; or being lost: and perishing, or dying: or [used as substs.] loss, or diminution; or the state of being lost: and perdition, or death: (M, * A, K: *) and so ↓ tabaAbN, (T, S, A, Msb, K,) [said to be] a subst. from tab~abahu, with teshdeed, (Msb,) and ↓ tababN and ↓ tabiybN: (K:) or the last three signify [simply] perdition, or death: (M:) and ↓ tatobiybN is explained as signifying loss, or diminution, that brings, or leads, to perdition or death; (IAth, TA;) and so ↓ tabaAbN; (Bd in cxi. 1;) and the causing to perish. (T, TA.) Hence you say, ↓ tab~a tabaAbFA [meaning, in an emphatic manner, May he suffer loss, or be lost, or perish]. (S.) And tab~FA lahu May God decree to him loss, or perdition; or cause loss, or perdition, to cleave to him: (S, M, * Msb, * K: *) tab~FA being in the accus. case as an inf. n. governed by a verb understood. (S.) And ↓ tab~FA tabiybFA, [in the CK tatobiybFA,] meaning the same in an intensive, or emphatic, manner: (M, K:) and ↓ tab~FA tabaAbFA. (TA.) And tab~ato yadaAhu, (T, S, M, K,) and tab~ato yaduhu, aor.
tabi3a , (Msb,) inf. n. tab~N and ↓ tabaAbN, but IDrd says that the former of these seems to be the inf. n., and the latter the simple subst., (M,) May his arms, or hands, and his arm, or hand, suffer loss, or be lost, or perish: (T, M, Msb, K, and Bd in cxi. 1:) or (tropical:) may he himself suffer loss, &c., (Msb, * and Bd ubi suprà,) i. e., (tropical:) his whole person: (Jel in cxi. 1:) or (tropical:) his good in the present life and that in the life to come. (Bd ubi suprà.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tab~a (A, TA) and ↓ tabotaba (T, K) (tropical:) He became an old man: (T, A, K:) the loss of youth being likened to tabaAba. (TA.) -A2- tab~a, [aor., accord. to rule,
tabu3a ,] He cut, or cut off, a thing. (K.) And tub~a It was cut, or cut off. (TA.)

2 tb~b tbb , inf. n. tatobiybN: see 1, in three places. -A2- , tb~bhu (inf. n. as above, S,) [He caused him to suffer loss, or to become lost: or] he destroyed him, or killed him. (S, K.) ― -b2- He said to him tab~FA: (M, K: *) [i. e.] he imprecated loss, or perdition, or death, upon him. (A.)
4 Atb~ A@ll~`hu quw~atahu * (tropical:) God weakened, or impaired, or may God weaken, or impair, his strength. (K, TA.)

10 Asttb~ A^sttb Asttb {sttAb {sttb (tropical:) It (a road) became beaten, or trodden, and rendered even, or easy to walk or ride upon, or easy and direct. (A.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (an affair) was, or became, rightly disposed or arranged; in a right state: (S, M, A, Msb:) or it followed a regular, or right, course; was in a right state; and clear, or plain: from musotatib~N applied to a road, explained below: (T, TA:) or it became complete, and in a right state: lit. it demanded loss, or diminution, or destruction; because these sometimes follow completeness: (Har p. 35:) or the b may be a substitute for m; the meaning being Asttm~. (TA.)
R. Q. 1 tabotaba tbtb : see 1.

tib~apN bhy tb tbh tbp
A difficult, or distressing, state or condition. (K.)
tababN tbb : see 1, in several places.
tabaAbN tbAb : see 1, in several places.
tabiybN tbyb : see 1, in several places.

tab~uwbN bwb tbwb
i. q. maholakapN [A place of perdition, or destruction; or a desert; or a desert such as is termed mafaAzap]. (K.) -A2- [It is also said in the K to signify What the ribs infold: but I think it probable that this meaning has been assigned to it from its having been found erroneously written for tabuwtN, a dial. var. of taAbuwtN.]

taAb~N A^bY tA^b tAb (tropical:) An old man; (AZ, T, M, A, K;) fem. with p: (AZ, T, M, A:) and (assumed tropical:) weak: pl. A^atobaAbN: of the dial. of Hudheyl; and extr. [with respect to analogy]. (M.) You say, kunotu $aAb~FA faSirotu taAb~FA [I was a young man, and I have become an old man]. (A.) And A^a$aAb~apN A^anoti A^amo taAb~apN [Art thou a young woman or an old woman?] (A.) ― -b2- Also, (T, K,) or taAb~u AlZ~ahori, (T,) (assumed tropical:) An ass, and a camel, having galls, or sores, on his back: (T, K:) pl. as above. (K.) ― -b3- [See also baAt~N.]

musotatib~N msttb , applied to a road, (tropical:) Furrowed by passengers, so that it is manifest to him who travels along it; and to this is likened an affair that is clear, or plain, and in a right state. (T.) [See the verb, 10.]

tabuwtN tbwt
i. q. taAbuwtN; (K;) a dial. var. of the latter. (TA.) See both in art. twb.

1 tabira A^bAr A^br bAr br brY tbr , aor.
tabara , (Lth, T, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. tabaArN; (Lth, T, M;) and tabara, aor.
tabura ; (Msb;) He, or it, (a thing, Lth, T, M,) perished. (Lth, T, M, Msb, K.) -A2- See also 2.

2 tb~rhu A^bAr A^br brY tbr tbrh tbrp , inf. n. tatobiyrN; (Zj, T, S, M, Msb, * K;) and ↓ tabarahu, aor.
tabira , inf. n. taborN; (K;) He broke it: (K:) or he broke it in pieces; (S, M;) and did away with it: (M:) or he crumbled it, or broke it into small pieces, with his fingers: (Zj, T:) and he destroyed it: (Zj, T, S, Msb, K:) He (God) destroyed him. (A.)

tiborN A^bAr A^br bAr br brY tbr [a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p: Native gold, in the form of dust or of nuggets: this is the sense in which the word is generally used in the present day:] broken gold: (M:) it is not so called unless in the dust of its mine, or broken: (IJ, M:) or gold, and silver, before it is wrought: (Lth, T, IF, Msb:) or broken, or crumbled, particles of gold, and of silver, before they are wrought: when they are wrought, they are called *ahabN and fiD~apN: (IAar, T, K:) or uncoined gold (S, Mgh, Msb) and silver: (Mgh:) when coined, it is called EayonN: (S, Msb:) [properly,] the term tbr should not be employed save as applied to gold; but some apply it to silver also: (S:) the tbr of silver, as well as of gold, is mentioned in a trad.: (TA:) or gold (M, K) universally: (M:) and silver: (K:) or what is extracted from the mine, (M, K,) of gold and silver and all jawaAhir [here meaning native ores] of the earth, (M,) before it is wrought (M, K) and used: (M:) or any jawohar [or native ore] before it is used, of copper (Zj, T, Mgh, Msb) and brass (Zj, T, Mgh) or iron (Msb) &c.: (Zj, Mgh, Msb:) and any jwhr [or native ore] that is used, of copper and brass: (K:) the word is sometimes applied to other minerals than gold and silver, as copper and iron and lead, but generally to gold; and some say that its primary application is to gold, and that the other applications are later, or tropical: (TA:) also broken pieces of glass. (Zj, T, M, K.)
tiboriyapN A^br brY tbryh tbryp a dial. var. of hiboriyapN, (AO, S,) i. e. [Scurf on the head;] what is formed at the roots of the hair, like bran. (AO, S, K.)

tabaArN A^bAr bArY tbAr
Destruction, or perdition: (Zj, T, S, M, &c.:) inf. n. of tabira. (Lth, T, M.)

mutab~arN mtbr
Broken up [and] destroyed: so in [the saying in the Kur vii. 135,] h`w^ulaA='i mutab~arN maA humo fiyhi [As to these people, that wherein they are shall be broken up and destroyed]. (S.) ― -b2- raA^oYN mutab~arN Counsel destroyed, or brought to nought. (TA, from a trad.)
matobuwrN mtbwr [Destroyed;] in a state of destruction: (IAar, T, K:) and defective, or deficient. (IAar, T.)

1 tabiEahu A^bAE bAE tbE tbEh tbEp , (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
tabaEa , inf. n. tabaEN (S, Msb, K) and tabaAEapN, (S, K,) He followed; or went, or walked, behind, or after; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) him, (Mgh, Msb, K,) or it; namely, a people, or company of men: (S:) or [in the CK “ and ”] he went with him, or it, when the latter had passed by him: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and ↓ Ait~abaEahu signifies the same; (Lth, S, K *) and so does ↓ A^atobaEahu: (Lth, Mgh, K:) or ↓ A^atobaEotuhumo signifies I overtook them, they having gone before me; (Fr, * A'Obeyd, S, Msb, * K;) as also tabiEotuhumo: (Fr, K:) Akh says that tabiEotuhu and ↓ A^atobaEotuhu signify the same: and hence the saying in the Kur [xxxvii. 10], $ihaAbN vaAqibN ↓ faA^atobaEahu [and a shooting star piercing the darkness by its light overtaketh him]: (S:) and the saying in the same [vii. 174], ↓ faA^atobaEahu Al$~ayoTaAnu and the devil overtook him: (TA:) and
the saying in the same [xx. 81], firoEawonu ↓ faA^atobaEahumo bijunuwdihi and Pharaoh overtook them with his troops: or almost did so: (Ibn-'Arafeh, K:) or this signifies made his troops to follow them; (TA;) the b, accord. to some, being redundant: (Bd:) or ↓ A^atobaEahu signifies he followed his footsteps; and sought him, following him: (TA:) but ↓ Ait~abaEahumo signifies he went [after them, or followed them,] when they had passed by him; as also tabiEahumo, inf. n. tabaEN: you say, ↓ Hat~aY A^atobaEotuhumo ↓ maA zilotu A^at~abiEuhumo, i. e. [I ceased not to follow them] until I overtook them: (A'Obeyd:) Fr says that ↓ A^atobaEa is better than ↓ Ait~abaEa; for the latter signifies he went behind, or after, him, when the latter person was going along; but when you say, ↓ A^atobaEotuhu, it is as though [you meant that] you followed his footsteps: (TA:) and ↓ fulaAnN fulaAnFA ↓ Ait~abaEa [as in the L and TA, but perhaps a mistake for ↓ A^atobaEa,] signifies also he followed him, desiring to do evil to him; like as Pharaoh followed Moses: (L, TA:) some say, tabiEotu Al$~aYo'a, inf. n. tubuwEN, meaning I went after the thing: and tabiEa Al$~aYo'a, inf. n. tabaEN and tabaAEN, (assumed tropical:) [he followed the thing] in respect of actions: (L, TA:) you say, tabiEa AlA_imaAma (assumed tropical:) he followed the Imám [by doing as he did]: (Msb:) [but in this last sense, more commonly,] one says, ↓ Ait~abaEahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) he did like as he [another] did: (TA:) and AlquroA=na ↓ Ait~abaEa (assumed tropical:) he followed the Kurán as his guide; did according to what is in it: (TA:) and you say also, EalaY AlA^amori ↓ taAbaEahu; (Msb;) or ElY ka*aA, inf. n. mutaAbaEapN and tibaAEN; (S;) (assumed tropical:) [he followed him, or imitated him, in the affair;] (Msb;) he followed him, or imitated him, in doing such a thing: (PS:) [but this last phrase has another meaning: see 3.] In the saying, laA yutobaEu binaArK A_ilaY Alqabori, [in which the verb may be pass. of tabiEa or of ↓ A^atobaEa,] or, accord. to one relation, ↓ lA yut~abaEu, each in the pass. form, [Fire shall not be made to follow to the grave, though it may be rendered one shall not follow with fire to the grave, it is said that] the b is to render the verb transitive. (Mgh.) ― -b2- tabiEotu Alr~ajula biHaq~iY; and bihi ↓ taAbaEotuhu, inf. n. mutaAbaEapN [and probably tbaAEN also]; and bh ↓ Ait~abaEotuhu; I prosecuted, or sued, the man for my right, or due. (TA.) The saying in the Kur [ii. 173], biA@lomaEoruwfi ↓ faA@t~ibaAEN means [Then] prosecution for the bloodwit [shall be made with lenity]. (TA.) ― -b3- tabiEa, of which the aor., yatobaE, occurs in a trad., [see 4,] (Mgh, TA,) pronounced by the relaters of trads. with teshdeed, [↓ yat~abiE,] (TA,) also signifies (assumed tropical:) He accepted a reference from his debtor to another for the payment of what was owed to him. (Mgh, TA. *)

2 tab~aEa A@ll~`hu lifulaAnK * , inf. n. tatobiyEN, May God make a thing to be followed by another thing to such a one, is said in relation to good and to evil; like sab~aEa lahu. (TA in art. sbE.) -A2- See also 5.

3 tibaAEN A^bAE byE tbAE [and mutaAbaEapN, the inf. ns. of taAbaEa,] i. q. wilaA='N [The making a consecution, or succession, of one to the other, bayona A^amorayoni between two things, or affairs: and the making consecutive, successive, or uninterrupted, in its progressions, or gradations, or the like: see 6]. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., taAbiEuwA bayona AlHaj~i wAlEumorapi [Make ye a consecution between the Hj~ and the Emrp; meaning make ye the performance of the Hj~ and that of the Emrp to be consecutive]; (TA;) i. e. when ye perform the Hj~, then perform ye the Emrp; and when ye perform the Emrp, then perform ye the Hj~: or when ye perform either of these, then perform ye after it the other, without any length of time [intervening]: but the former [meaning] is the more obvious. (Marginal note in a copy of the Jámi'-es-Sagheer of Es-Suyootee.) And you say, taAbiEo bayonanaA wabayonahumo EalaY AlxayoraAti (assumed tropical:) Make thou us to be followers, or imitators, of them in excellencies. (TA.) And tAbE AlA^agaAniY~a [He sang songs consecutively, successively, or uninterruptedly]. (S and K in art. jr.) And tAbE A_isoqaATahu [He made it to fall, fall down, drop, drop down, or tumble down, in consecutive portions or quantities]. (M and K in art. sqT: in the CK AasoqATahu.) And tAbE Alfarasu AljaroYa (assumed tropical:) [The horse prosecuted, or continued, the course, or running, uninterruptedly]. (K voce halaba; &c.) And huwa yataAbiEu AlHadiyva (tropical:) He carries on the narrative, or discourse, by consecutive progressions, or uninterruptedly: or, as Z says, pursues it, or carries it on, well. (TA.) [See also a similar phrase in what here follows.] ― -b2- tAbE Alqawosa He pared, or trimmed, the bow well, giving to each part thereof what was its due. (K, TA.) Skr says that the phrase tuwbiEa baroyuhaA, used by Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhalee in describing a bow, means The paring, or trimming, of which has been executed with uniformity, part after part. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (TA,) the saying of Abu-l-Wákid ElLeythee, (S, TA,) in a trad., (S,) taAbaEonaA AlA^aEomaAla falamo najido $ayoy^FA A^abolaga fiY Talabi AlA=xirapi mina Alz~uhodi fiY Ald~unoyaA (S, TA) (assumed tropical:) We have practised works with diligence, and acquired a sound knowledge of them, [and we have not found anything more efficacious in the pursuit of the blessings of the world to come than abstinence in respect of the enjoyments of the present world.] (S, * TA.) You say also, tAbE Eamalahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He made his work sound, or free from defect: (Kr, S:) and in like manner, kalaAmahu his language, or speech. (Kr.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] tAbE AlmaroEaY AlA_ibila (tropical:) The pasture fattened the camels well and thoroughly. (K, TA.) ― -b5- tAbEhu EalaY AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) He aided, assisted, or helped, him to do the thing, or affair. (TA.) ― -b6- See also 1, where another meaning of the same phrase is mentioned, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b7- taAbaEotuhu biHaq~iY: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

4 AtbEhu A^tbE A^tbEh AtbEh AtbEp tbE {tbE {tbEh : see 1, from the beginning nearly to the end. -A2- Also He made him to follow; or to overtake: (S, K:) he made him to be a follower: (Mgh, Msb:) or he urged him, or induced him, to be a follower. (Mgh.) You say, [making the verb doubly trans.,] A^atobaEotuhumo gayoriY [I made them to follow, or overtake, another, not myself]. (K.) And A^atobaEotuhu Al$~aYo'a fatabiEahu [I made him to follow, or overtake, the thing, and he followed it, or overtook it]. (S.) And A^atobaEotu zayodFA EamorFA I made Zeyd to be a follower of 'Amr: (Mgh, Msb:) or I urged, or induced, Zeyd to be a follower of 'Amr. (Mgh.) And A^atobaEahu nafosahu mutaHas~irFA EalaY maA faAta (assumed tropical:) [He made his mind, or desire, to follow after it, regretting what had passed away]. (TA in art. Ejz.) [See also 10.] It is said in a prov., (TA,) A^atobiEi Alfarasa lijaAmahaA [Make thou its bit and bridle to follow the horse]: or Aln~aAqapa zimaAmahaA [her nose-rein, the she-camel]: or Ald~alowa ri$aA='ahaA [its rope, the bucket]: used in bidding to complete a favour, or benefaction: (K, TA:) A'Obeyd says, I think the meaning of the first prov. to be, Thou hast liberally given the horse, and the bit and bridle are a smaller matter; therefore satisfy thou completely the want, seeing that the horse is not without need of the bit and bridle. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence the trad., mano A^utobiEa EalaY maliYo'K faloyatobaEo (tropical:) Whoso is referred, for the payment of what is owed to him, to a solvent man, let him accept the reference: (Mgh, TA: *) [see also 1, last meaning:] the verb being made trans. by means of ElY because it conveys the meaning of A_iHaAlapN. (Mgh.) You say [also], A^utobiEa fulaAnN bifulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one was referred, for the payment of what was owed to him, to such a one. (S, TA.) And A^atobaEahu Ealayohi (tropical:) He referred him, for the payment of what was owed to him, to him. (TA.) ― -b3- [See also A_itobaAEN, below.]

5 ttb~Ehu A^tbE tbE ttbE ttbEh ttbEp {tbE , inf. n. tatab~uEN, (Lth, S, Msb, * K,) for which ↓ Ait~ibaAEN is used by El-Kutámee, tropically, (S,) or, accord. to Sb, because the same in meaning; (TA;) and ↓ tbE~h, inf. n. tatobiyEN; (S, K; *) He pursued it; investigated it; examined it; hunted after it; prosecuted a search after it; made successive, or repeated, endeavours to attain it, to reach it, or to obtain it; or sought it, sought for it, or sought after it, successively, time after time, or repeatedly, or in a leisurely manner, by degrees, gradually, step by step, bit by bit, or one thing after another, (Lth, S, * Msb, K, * TA,) following after it. (S.) Hence the saying of Zeyd Ibn-Thábit, respecting the collecting of the Kur-án, faEaliqotu A^atatab~aEuhu mina All~ixaAfi waAlEusubi [And I set myself to seeking to collect it successively, &c., from the thin white stones and the leafless palm-branches upon which it was written]. (TA.) And ttb~E AlbilaAda yaxoruju mino A^aroDK A_ilaY A^aroDK [He investigated the countries, going forth from land to land]. (S and K in art. qrY.) And fulaAnN yatatab~aEu A^avara fulaAnK [Such a one pursues, &c., the track of such a one]. (TA.) And yatatab~aEu masaAwiYa fulaAnK [He seeks successively, &c., to discover the vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions, of such a one]. (TA.) And yatatab~aEu madaAq~a AlA^umuwri wanaHowa *`lika [He pursues small, or little, affairs; and the like thereof: or he seeks successively, &c., to obtain a knowledge of the subtilties, niceties, abstrusities, or obscuri-
ties, of things, or affairs; and the like thereof]. (TA.) And ttb~E AlHabola [He took successive holds of the rope]: said of a man descending from a part of a mountain such as is termed $iyq, by means of a rope tied to that part, to a place in which honey was deposited. (TA in art. $yq.)

6 ttAbE tAbE ttAbE
It was, or became, consecutive, successive, or uninterrupted, in its progressions, or gradations, or the like; syn. tawaAlaY. (K.) You say, ttAbE suquwTuhu [Its falling, falling down, dropping, dropping down, or tumbling down, was, or became, consecutive, &c.; i. e. it fell, fell down, &c., in consecutive portions or quantities]. (M and K in art. sqT.) And ttAbE Alqawomu The people, or company of men, followed one another. (Msb.) And tataAbaEati AlA^a$oyaA='u, and AlA^amoTaAru, and AlA^umuwru, The things, and the rains, and the events, came one after another, each following near upon another. (Lth.) And it is said in a trad., tataAbaEato EalaY qurayo$K sinuw jadobK [Years of dearth, drought, or sterility, came consecutively upon Kureysh]. (TA.) ― -b2- ttAbE Alfarasu (tropical:) The horse ran evenly, not raising one of his limbs [above its fellow]. (TA.) ― -b3- ttAbEt AlA_ibilu (tropical:) The camels became fat and goodly. (TA.)
8 A_it~abaEa see 1, throughout: and see also 5.

10 AsttbEhu A^sttbEh AsttbEh AsttbEp {sttbE {sttbEh
He desired, or demanded, of him that he should follow him: (TA:) or he made him to follow him. (L.) [See also 4.]

tiboEN A^bAE bAE byE tbE
A follower of women: (Lh, * Az:) or a passionate lover, and follower, of a woman, (K,) whithersoever she goes: (TA:) and with p, of a man: (Lh:) and ↓ tub~aEN a sedulous seeker of women. (K.) [See taAbiEN.] You say also, huwa tiboEu Dil~apK, meaning He is a follower of women: and tiboEu Dil~apN one in whom is no good, and with whom is no good: or, accord. to Th, you only say tiboEu Dil~apK. (TA.) ― -b2- h`*aA tiboEu h`*aA This is what follows this. (M in art. tlw.) ― -b3- See also tabiyEN, in two places.
tabaEN A^bAE bAE byE tbE : see taAbiEN, in six places.

rajulN tubaEN lilokalaAmi rjl tbE llklAm
A man who makes his speech consecutive, one part to another. (Yoo, K. *)

baqarapN taboEaY bqrp tbEY bqrp tbEy
A cow desiring [and therefore following] the bull. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

tabiEapN A^bAE bAE tbE tbEh tbEp and ↓ tibaAEapN signify the same; (T, S, O, L, K;) [The consequence of an action: and] a claim which one seeks to obtain for an injury, or injurious treatment, and the like: (T, O, L, K; and so the Msb in explanation of the former word:) the former is also explained as signifying a right, or due, annexed to property, claimed from the possessor of the property: (L:) pl. [of the former] tabiEaAtN and [of the latter] tibaAEaAtN. (TA.) A poet says,
zamana Alt~aqaH~umi waAlmajaAEaho
A^akalato Haniyfapu rab~ahaA
↓ suwo'a AlEawaAqibi waAlt~ibaAEaho
lamo yaHo*aruwA mino rab~ihimo
[Haneefeh ate their lord, in the time of experiencing dearth, or drought, or sterility, and hunger: they did not fear, from their lord, the evil of the results, and the consequence of their action]: for they had taken to themselves a god consisting of Hayos, [i. e. dates mixed with clarified butter and the preparation of milk called A^aqiT, kneaded together,] and worshipped it for some time; then famine befell them, and they ate it. (S.) And one says, maA Ealayohi mina A@ll~`hi fiY h`*aA tabiEapN, and ↓ tibaAEapN, There is not, against him, on the part of God, in this, any claim on account of wrong-doing. (TA.)

tabiyEN A^bAE bAE tbyE [One who is prosecuted, or sued, for a right, or due; of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, from tabiEotuhu biHaq~iY;] one who owes property to another, (S, K, TA,) and whom the latter prosecutes, or sues, for it. (TA.) -A2- The young one of a cow in the first year; (S, Msb, K;) so says Aboo-Fak'as El-Asadee: (TA:) or that is a year old; (Az, Mgh, TA;) not so called until he has completed the year; erroneously said by Lth to signify a calf ripening to his perfect state: (Az, TA:) thus called because he yet follows his mother; (Mgh, Msb;) the word in this sense being of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN: (Msb:) and ↓ tiboEN signifies the same: (TA:) fem. of the former with p: (S, Msb, K:) pl. tibaAEN and tabaAy^iEN; (AA, S, O, K;) both pls. of tabiyEN; (AA, S, O;) or the former is pl. of tabiyEapN; (Msb;) and the pl. of tabiyEN is A^atobiEapN [a pl. of pauc.]; (L, Msb;) and A^ataAbiEu and A^ataAbiyEu, the latter of which is extr., are pls. of A^atobiEapN: (L:) the pl. of ↓ tiboEN in the abovementioned sense is A^atobaAEN. (TA.) Accord. to EshShaabee, (IF,) One whose horns and ears are equal [in length]: (IF, K:) but this is a judicial explanation; not deduced from the rules of lexicology. (IF.) ― -b2- I. q. ↓ taAbiEN [as signifying One who prosecutes, or sues, for a right, or due; and particularly for blood-revenge]. (S, K.) Hence the saying in the Kur [xvii. 71], vum~a laA tajiduwA lakumo EalayonaA bihi tabiyEFA Then ye shall not find for you any to prosecute for blood-revenge, nor any to sue, against us therein: (Fr. S, K:) or ye shall not find for you any to sue us for the disallowing of what hath befallen you, nor for our averting it from you: (Zj:) [or any aider against us; for] tabiyEN also signifies an aider; and especially against an enemy. (Lth, K.) ― -b3- See also taAbiEN, latter half.
tibaAEapN tbAE tbAEh tbAEp : see tabiEapN, in three places.

tub~aEN A^bAE bAE byE tbE
An appellation of each of the Kings of El-Yemen (S, K) who possessed Himyer and Hadramowt, (K, TA,) and, as some add, Sebà; (TA;) but not otherwise; (K, TA;) and the like of this is said in the 'Eyn: (TA:) so called because they followed one another; whenever one died, another took his place, following him in his course of acting: (TA:) pl. tabaAbiEapN, (S, K,) with p added as having the meaning of a rel. n.; [as though it were pl. of tub~aEiY~N, like as HanaAbilapN is pl. of HanobaliY~N;] erroneously written in some of the copies of the K ttAbEp: (TA:) the tbAbEp of Himyer were like the A^akaAsirap of the Persians and the qayaASirap of the Romans. (Lth.) In the Kur xliv. 36, it is said in a trad. to mean a particular king, who was a believer, and whose people were unbelievers. (Zj.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) A species of the yaEaAsiyb [or kings of the bees], (K,) the greatest and most beautiful thereof, whom the other bees follow: (TA:) pl. tabaAbiyEu; (K;) in the L, tataAbiEu [which is probably a mistranscription for tabaAbiEu]. (TA.) ― -b3- A species of Tayor [which means any flying things, as well as birds; and may therefore, perhaps, be meant to indicate what next precedes]. (S.) ― -b4- The shade, or shadow; (S, K;) because it follows the sun; as also ↓ tub~uEN. (K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Soadà El-Juhaneeyeh, (TA,) or Selmà El-Juhaneeyeh, (marginal note in a copy of the S,) bewailing her brother, As'ad,
yaridu AlmiyaAhu HaDiyrapN wanafiyDapF
wiroda AlqaTaApi A_i*aA A@somaA^al~a Alt~ub~aEu
(S) [He comes to the waters when people are dwelling, or staying, there, (but see HaDiyrapN,) and when no one is there, as the bird called katáh comes to water] when the shade has become contracted at mid-day: or, accord. to Aboo-Leylà, the meaning is, the shade of night; i. e., this man comes to the waters in the last part of the night, before any one: though it means also the shade of day-time: (TA:) or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed Ed- Dareer, the meaning here is [the star, or asterism, called] Ald~abaraAn; and this is very probably correct; for the bird above mentioned comes to the waters by night, and seldom by day; and hence the saying, A^adal~u mino qaTaApK. (Az, TA.) See taAbiEN. ― -b5- See also tiboEN. ― -b6- maA A^adoriY A^aY~u tub~aEK huwa I know not who of men he is. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b7- tub~aEN is also a pl. of taAbiEN [q. v.]. (TA.)
tub~uEN A^bAE bAE byE tbE : see tub~aEN.

tab~uwEu Al$~amosi *
A certain wind, (K, TA,) also called Aln~ukayobaA='u, (TA,) which blows (K, TA) in the early morning, (TA,) with the rising of the sun, (K, TA,) from the direction of the wind called AlS~abaA, unaccompanied by rising clouds, (TA,) and veers round through the various places whence winds blow until it returns to the place from which blows the wind called AlSbA, (K, TA,) whence it commenced in the early morning: (TA:) the Arabs dislike it. (Z, TA.)

taAbiEN tAbE
Following; a follower: (TA:) and ↓ tabaEN also signifies the same as taAbiEN; (K;) a thing that follows in the track of a thing; (Lth, Az;) or that is at the kinder, or latter, part of anything; (TA;) but is used alike as sing. and pl.: (S, Msb, K:) the pl. of taAbiEN is tub~aEN and tub~aAEN (TA) [and, applied to rational beings, taAbiEuwna]: and the pl. of ↓ tabaEN is A^atobaAEN; (S, K;) or this may be used as a pl. of tabaEN; (Msb;) or it is pl. of taAbiEN, like
as xadamN is pl. of xaAdimN, (Kr, Mgh,) and TalabN of TaAlibN, &c.; (K;) or, correctly speaking, it is a quasi-pl. n. (Sb, TA.) You say, ↓ AlmuSal~iY tabaEN lAimaAmihi [The person praying is a follower of his Imám]: and Aln~aAsu tabaEN lahu [The people are followers of him]. (Msb.) And it is said in the Kur [xiv. 24, and xl. 50], ↓ A_in~aA kun~aA lakumo tabaEFA [Verily we were followers of you]: (S, TA:) in which the last word may be a quasi-pl. n. of taAbiEN; or it may be an inf. n., meaning *awiY tabaEK. (TA.) ↓ tabaEN is applied as an epithet to the legs of a beast: (Lth, T:) and is also used as [an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] signifying The legs of a beast. (K.) ― -b2- A jinnee, or genie, that accompanies a woman and follows her whithersoever she goes, (K, TA,) loving her: (TA:) and taAbiEapN a jinneeyeh, or female genie, that does the same to a man: (S, * K, TA:) or the p is added in the latter to give intensiveness to the signification, or to denote evilness of nature, or to convey the meaning of daAhiyapN, q. v.: the pl. is tawaAbiEu: and this means female associates. (TA.) ― -b3- A servant; as also ↓ tabiyEN. (TA.) A^awi Alt~aAbiEiyna gayori A^uwliY AlA_irobapi, in the Kur [xxiv. 31], accord. to Th, means Or the servants of the husband, such as the old man who is perishing by reason of age, and the aged woman. (TA.) ― -b4- See also tabiyEN. ― -b5- [Also One next in the order of time after the SaHaAbap; like ↓ taAbiEiY~N. ― -b6- And in grammar, An appositive.] ― -b7- taAbiEu Aln~ajomi [The follower of the asterism; i. e., of the Pleiades;] a name of Ald~abaraAn [the Hyades; or the five chief stars thereof; or the brightest star among them, a of Taurus]: this name being given to it as ominous of good; (K;) or as ominous of evil: (O:) or so called because it follows the Pleiades: (T:) also called Alt~aAbiEu, (T in art. dbr, Sh, IB, and others,) and ↓ tuwayobiEN, (K,) which is the dim., (TA,) or Alt~uwayobiEu, (T in art. dbr,) and ↓ tub~aEN, (K,) or Alt~ub~aEu [q. v.], (Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer, T,) and ↓ Alt~abaEu, (IB, Z,) and Alt~aAliY, and AlHaAdiY, (IB,) or HAdY Aln~ujuwmi , (S in art. jdH ,) or HAdY Aln~ajomi . (Kzw and others.) [See also AlmijodaHu.] taAbiEiY~N: see taAbiEN.
tuwayobiEN twybE : see taAbiEN, last sentence.

A_itobaAEN A^tbAE AtbAE tbE {tbAE in language is when one says the like of HasanN basanN (S, K) and qabiyHN $aqiyHN: (S:) The putting, after a word, an imitative sequent, i. e. another word similar to the former in measure or in its rawiY~, by way of pleonasm, or for fulness of expression, and for corroboration; (Mz 28th nwE, and Kull p. 11;) the latter word being one not used alone, and having no meaning by itself, as in bsanNa HasanN; or being one which has a meaning of its own, as in haniyoy^FA mariyoy^FA . (Kull ubi suprà.) ― -b2- [Also The latter of such two words; i. e. an imitative sequent. ― -b3- And used in the former sense, as an inf. n., it denotes various other kinds of assimilation, i. e., of one word to another preceding or following it, and of one vowel to another preceding or following it in the same word.]

mutobiEN mtbE She who has with her children, or young ones: (Lh:) or a ewe, or she-goat, and a cow, and a girl, having her offspring following her: (K:) or a cow having a tabiyE, q. v.: and IB mentions also mutobiEapN as signifying the same: and a female servant followed by her offspring whither she comes and goes. (TA.)

matobuwEN mtbwE [pass. part. n. of 1. ― -b2- In grammar, The antecedent of a taAbiE, i. e., of an appositive.] mutaAbaEN (assumed tropical:) Anything made, or executed, soundly, thoroughly, well, or so as to be free from defect. (K, * TA.)

mutataAbiEN mttAbE
Consecutive, successive, or uninterrupted, in its progressions, or gradations, or the like. (TA.) You say luw^oluw^N mutataAbiEN Pearls following one another, or doing so in uninterrupted order. (TA.) And SiyaAmu $ahorayoni mutataAbiEayoni The fasting of two consecutive months. (TA.) ― -b2- guSonN mutataAbiEN (tropical:) An even, or a uniform, branch, in which are no knots. (K, * TA.) And farasN mutataAbiEu Alxaloqi (tropical:) A horse symmetrical in make, (A, K,) justly proportioned in his limbs or parts. (A, TA.) And rajulN mutataAbiEu AlEilomi (tropical:) A man whose knowledge is uniform, consistent, without incongruity. (K, * TA.)

1 tabalahu A^bAl A^bl A^blY bAl bl blA blh bly tbl tblh tblp wbl , (Lth, T, M,) aor.
tabila , (M,) inf. n. tabolN, (Lth, T, M,) He pursued him with enmity, or hostility: (Lth, T:) or he bore enmity, or was hostile, to him. (M.) ― -b2- tabalahumu Ald~ahoru, (S, M, K,) inf. n. tabolN, (M,) (tropical:) Time, or fortune, smote them with its vicissitudes, (M, K,) and (K) destroyed them; (S, K;) as also ↓ A^atobalahumo. (S, TA.) ― -b3- tabalahu AlHub~u, (S, M,) or AlhawaY, (T,) aor.
tabila , (M,) inf. n. tabolN; (T, K;) and ↓ Atblhu, (S, M,) inf. n. A_itobaAlN; (K, TA;) Love made him sick, or ill; (T, S, M, K; [in the CK, wAlAasoqaAmu kAlAatobaAli is erroneously put for wAlA_isoqaAmu kAlA_itobaAli;]) and caused him to be in a bad, or unsound, state: (S:) or, as some say, tabalahu signifies, (M,) or signifies also, (K,) it took away his reason, (M, K,) and bewildered him. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, of a woman, tabalato fuw^aAda Alr~ajuli, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, as though meaning, (M,) She smote the man's heart with ↓ tabol [app. meaning love-sickness]. (M, K.) -A2- See also Q. Q. 1.
2 tab~ala and 3: see Q. Q. 1.

4 Atblhu A^tblh Atblh Atblp tbl , inf. n. A_itobaAlN, He made him a victim of blood-revenge, or retaliation of murder or homicide. (S: the meaning is indicated there, but not expressed.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places.

Q. Q. 1 tawobala Alqidora twbl Alqdr , (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, Msb, K,) and taA^obalahaA, with hemz, (IJ, M,) or ↓ taAbalahaA, [without ',] (K,) mentioned by Ibn-Abbád in the Moheet, (TA,) and ↓ tab~alahaA, (T, M, K,) said by Lth to be allowable, (T,) and ↓ tabalahaA, (K,) He seasoned [the contents of] the cooking-pot with taAbal; (Msb;) he put taAbal into the cooking-pot; (K;) i. q. qaz~aHahaA and faH~aAhaA: (A 'Obeyd, T:) from taAbalN. (S, M. *) ― -b2- [Hence,] tawobala kalaAmahu (tropical:) He seasoned [meaning he embellished] his speech, or language; syn. qaz~aHahu (TA) and baz~arahu. (A in art. bzr.)

tabolN A^bAl A^bl A^blY bAl bl blA bly tbl wbl [originally inf. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- ] Enmity, or hostility, (Lth, T, M, K, TA,) in the heart, (TA,) with which one is pursued: (Lth, T:) pl. tubuwlN (Lth, T, M, K) and ↓ tabaAbiylu, which latter is extr. (K.) You say, liY Einodahu tabolN [He has enmity, or hostility, towards me, with which he pursues me]. (T.) ― -b3- I. q. tirapN (S) and *aHolN (S, M, K) [by the former of which may be intended the meaning explained above, or, as appears to be meant by the latter, blood-revenge; or retaliation of murder or homicide; or prosecution for blood; or a desire of, or seeking for, retaliation of a crime or of enmity]: pl. tubuwlN. (S.) Alt~abolu as meaning Al*~aHolu is likened by Yezeed Ibn-El- Hakam Eth-Thakafee to a debt which one should be paid. (Ham p. 530.) And one says, A^uSiyba bitabolK [He was made a victim of blood-revenge, or retaliation of murder or homicide: or, perhaps, of enmity, or hostility]. (S.) And bayonahumo tubuwlN [Between them are blood-revenges, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b4- Love-sickness. (Kull p. 167. [See Hub~u.]) See 1.

dahorN tabila dhr tbl , (M,) or ↓ taAbilN, (TA,) (tropical:) Time, or fortune, that smites people with its vicissitudes, (M, TA,) and destroys them. (TA.) And ↓ dahorN mutobilN xabilN, occurring in a poem of El-Aashà, (assumed tropical:) Time, or fortune, that destroys, or carries off, family and children. (S.)
tabiylN A^bAl tbyl : see matobuwlN.
tabaAbiylu tbAbyl : see tabolN.

tab~aAlN bAlY tbAl
A possessor [or seller] of tawaAbil pl. of taAbalN. (K.)

taAbalN tAbl , (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, Msb, K,) also pronounced taA^obalN, with ', (IJ, M,) and ↓ taAbilN, (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ tawobalu, (IAar, T, K,) Seeds (A^abozaArN Msb and K) that are used in cooking, for seasoning food; (T, S, * M, Msb, K;) i. q. faHFA; (T, M;) such as cumin-seeds and coriander-seeds: (TA voce qizoHN:) said to be arabicized: Ibn-El-Jawá- leekee says that the vulgar distinguish between tAbl and AbzAr, [in the manner explained voce bizorN,] but the [classical] Arabs do not: (Msb:) pl. tawaAbilu. (T, S, Msb, K.)
taAbilN tAbl : see tabilN: -A2- and see taAbalN.
tawobalu * : see taAbalN.

tuwbaAlN * [from the Persian tuwbaAlo or tuwPaAlo?] What falls in consecutive portions, or particles, on the occasion of the hammering of copper and of iron: a mivoqaAl thereof, with hydromel, drunk, powerfully alleviates the [ejection of] phlegm. (K.)
mutobilN mtbl : see tabilN.
matobuwlN mtbwl A man rendered love-sick; (T;) as also ↓ tabiylN: (M:) and the former, a lover who is not granted that which he wants. (TA.)

1 tabana A^bAn bAn bnY tAb tbn tbnn tbny , aor.
tabina , (S, M, K,) inf. n. tabonN, (S,) He fed a beast with tibon [q. v.]. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- Also He sold [tibon, i. e.] straw. (KL.) -A2- tabina, (T, S, M, K,) aor.
tabana , (S, K,) inf. n. tabanN, (T, S,) or tabonN, (M, K,) and tabaAnapN (T, S, * M, K) and tabaAniyapN, (M,) He was, or became, intelligent, sagacious, skilful, or knowing; syn. faTina, (K,) or SaAra faTinFA; (S;) and nice, or minute, in inspection (S, K) into affairs: (S:) or tabaAnapN signifies the being very intelligent or sagacious or skilful or knowing, and nice, or minute, in inspection; as also TabaAnahN; accord. to AO and AA: (T:) these two words signify the same (T, S, M *) accord. to [most of] the leading authorities: (T:) and Yaakoob asserts that the t is a substitute for T: (M:) [or the reverse seems to be the case in the opinion of Az, who here remarks that there are many instances of the change of t into T:] or the former is in evil; and the latter, in good: (M:) or, accord. to Lth, Tabina means in evil; and tabina, in good; so that he makes TbAnp to be in deceiving, or beguiling, and suddenly, or unexpectedly, attacking or destroying: but En-Nadr says the contr.; and accord. to him, TabanN signifies the having knowledge of affairs, and intelligence, or sagacity, and science: (T:) and ↓ tb~n, inf. n. tatobiynN signifies the same as tabina: (K:) or he inspected nicely, or minutely: as in a trad. in which it is said, respecting a woman whose husband has died leaving her pregnant, yunofaqu EalayohaA mino jamiyEi AlmaAli Hat~aY tab~anotumo maA tab~anotumo, meaning [She shall be expended upon from the whole of the property] until ye make a nice, or minute, inspection [into the circumstances of the case], and say otherwise, (T, S,) i. e., that she shall be expended upon from her own share: (T:) and so in another trad., in which it is said, A_in~a Alr~ajula layatakal~amu biAlkalimapi yutab~inu fiyhaA yahowiY bihaA fiY Aln~aAri, (A 'Obeyd, T, M,) i. e. [Verily a man will say a saying] in which he will be nice, or minute [in expression, whereby he will fall into the fire of Hell]: (TA:) here A 'Obeyd thinks the meaning to be the making language obscure, or abstruse, and disputing in a matter of religion. (T.) You say also, tabina lahu (T, M, TA) He understood it; or knew it; or had knowledge, or was cognizant, of it; (TA;) i. q. Tabina. (M.)
2 tb~n A^bAn bAn bnY tAb tbn tbnn tbny , inf. n. tatobiynN: see 1. -A2- tabon~hu, inf. n. as before, He clad him with a tub~aAn. (TA.)

8 Ait~abana A^tbn Atbn tbnY
He clad himself with a tub~aAn. (K.)
tabonN A^bAn bAn bnY tAb tbn tbnn tbny : see what next follows.

tibonN A^bAn bAn bnY tAb tbn tbnn tbny (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ tabonN (M, K) Straw; i. e. the stalks, or stems, (EaSiyf, M, K,) or the stalk, or stem, (saAq, Msb,) of seed-produce, (M, Msb, K,) such as wheat and the like, (M, K,) [generally] after it has been trodden or thrashed [and cut]; (Msb;) wheat when it has been trodden or thrashed [and cut] by the feet of beasts or by repeatedly drawing over it the [machine called] midowas [q. v.]: (Mgh in art. dws:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p [signifying a straw, or piece of straw]. (S, M.) You say A^aqal~u mino tibonapK [Less than a straw, or piece of straw]. (TA.) -A2- Also, the former, A great bowl: (S:) or a bowl that satisfies the thirst of twenty: (K:) or the greatest of bowls, that almost satisfies the thirst of twenty: (Ks, S, M:) next is the SaHon, which is nearly equal thereto: then, the Eus~, that satisfies the thirst of three and of four: then, the qadaH, that satisfies the thirst of two men: then, the qaEob, that satisfies the thirst of one man: then, the gumar: (Ks, S:) or a bowl of rude, or rough, make; not made neatly, or skilfully. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence, probably,] (assumed tropical:) A liberal, or bountiful, and noble, chief. (K.) ― -b3- And A wolf. (K.)

tabinN A^bAn bAn bnY tAb tbn tbnn tbny
Intelligent, sagacious, skilful, or knowing; and nice, or minute, in inspection (S, M, K) into affairs; (S;) as also TabinN: (M:) [or very intelligent, &c.: and accord. to some, in evil: or in good: see tabina.] ― -b2- And One who plays with his hand with everything. (K.)

tab~aAnN A^bAn tbAn
A seller of tibon: (S, M, K:) thus, perfectly decl., if of the measure faE~aAl, from Alt~ibonu: but if of the measure faEolaAn, from Alt~ab~u [the act of cutting (for tibon is generally cut by the thrashingmachine)], it is [tab~aAnu,] imperfectly decl. (S.)

tub~aAnN A^bAn tbAn
Small saraAwiyl [or breeches], (S, Mgh, K,) without legs, [i. e. having only two holes through which to put the legs,] (TA in art. vfr,) [made of linen, and of leather,] of the measure of a span, (S, Mgh,) such as to conceal the anterior and posterior pudenda (S, Mgh, K, TA) only; (TA;) worn by sailors (S, Mgh) [and by wrestlers]: or a thing like srAwyl: (M, Msb:) or a thing like small srAwyl: (T:) [it is an arabicized word, from the Persian tunobaAnN:] the Arabs make it masc. (T, M, Msb) and fem.: (Msb:) pl. tabaAbiynu. (T, Msb.)
tab~aAnapN tbAn tbAnh tbAnp (TA) and ↓ matobanapN (Mgh, Msb, TA) and ↓ matobanN (Mgh, Msb) The place, (TA,) or house, or the like, (Mgh, Msb,) of [or for] tibon. (Mgh, Msb, TA.)
matobanN mtbn : see tab~aAnapN.
matobanapN mtbn mtbnh mtbnp : see tab~aAnapN.
matobuwnN mtbwn , applied to a horse such as is termed biro*awn, Of the colour of tibon [or straw]. (TA.)
taAbuwhN A^bY tA^bwh tAb tAbwh tAbwp a dial. var. of taAbuwtN , of the dial. of the Ansár. (S and K in art. twb, q. v.)
taAbuwtN tAbwt : see art. twb. Accord. to some, it belongs to the present art., and was originally taAbuwapN.

Alt~ataru Alttr ttr [and Alt~ataAru and AltaAtaAru] A certain people, or nation, (K,) [called by us the Tartars,] in the furthest countries of the East, in the mountains of TgmAj, on the confines of China, (TA,) bordering upon the Turks, (K,) more than six months' journey from Má-waráä-n-nahr: so in the Murooj edh-Dhahab. (TA.)
tatoraY ttr ttrY ttry wtr and tatorFY: see art. wtr.

1 tajara A^jAr A^jr A^jrY jAr jr jrY tjr , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
tajura , (S, Msb,) inf. n. tajorN (S, Msb, K) and tijaArapN, (S, A, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) or quasi-inf. n., (Mgh,) and matojarN; (A;) and ↓ Ait~ajara, (S, A, Msb, K,) of the measure AifotaEala; (S;) He practised traffic, merchandise, or commerce; trafficked; traded; dealt; sold and bought; (K;) employed property for the purpose of gain. (A.) You say, tajara tijaArapF raAbiHapF [He practised a profitable, or lucrative, traffic]. (A.) And fiY ↓ fulaAnN yat~ajiru Albar~i wa AlbaHori [Such a one traffics on land and sea]. (A.) There can hardly, if at all, be found any other instance of t immediately followed by j except ntj and rtj: the t in tujaAha is originally w. (Msb.)
3 tAjrhu A^jr tA^jrh tAjr tAjrh tAjrp , (A,) inf. n. mutaAjarapN, (A, KL,) He practised with him [and (as is implied in the A) he vied with him in practising] traffic, or selling and buying. (KL.)
8 Ait~ajara A^tjr Atjr tjr {tjr : see 1, in two places. -A2- See also 8 in art. wjr.
tajorN A^jAr A^jr A^jrY jAr jr jrY tjr : see taAjirN.
Alt~ajiru Altjr : see taAjirN.

tijaArapN jArY tAjr tjArh tjArp a subst. from 1; (Msb;) or quasi-inf. n.; (Mgh;) [The practice of traffic, merchandise, or commerce; traffic; trade; selling and buying;] the trade of the taAjir, i. e., of him who sells and buys for gain; (Ksh in ii. 15;) the seeking of gain by selling and buying. (Bd ibid.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- Also Merchandise, meaning what is sold and bought, of goods, or commodities, or householdfurniture, and the like; a quasi-inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n. (Mgh.) [Hence the saying,] Ealayokumo bitijaArapi AlA=xirapi (tropical:) [Keep ye to the merchandise of the life to come]. (A.)

taAjirN A^jr tA^jr tAjr
A merchant; one who practises traffic, merchandise, or commerce; a trafficker; a trader, or tradesman; a dealer; one who sells and buys; (K;) one who sells and buys for gain: (Ksh in ii. 15:) and a vintner, or seller of wine, (S, K,) was also called thus by the Arabs: (S:) accord. to IAth, this latter is said to be the primary signification: and hence the saying in a trad., A_in~a Alt~aAjira faAjirN [Verily the vintner is a transgressor]: (TA:) pl. tuj~aArN and tijaArN and ↓ tajorN, (S, Msb, K,) [or rather this last is a quasi-pl. n.,] like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN, (S, Msb,) and tujurN, (K,) or this may be a pl. of tijaArN. (ISd, TA.) ↓ Alt~ajiru.
occurring in a verse of El-Akhtal, [for Alt~aAjiru,] is thought by ISd to be like TahirN [for TaAhirN]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A man skilful in an affair. (K, TA.) The Arabs say, A_in~ahu lataAjirN bi*`lika AlA^amori (tropical:) Verily he is skilful in that affair. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A she-camel that is saleable, or easy of sale, or in much demand, in traffic, and in the market; (A 'Obeyd, S, K;) as also taAjirapN: (K:) or the latter, a she-camel that is goodly, and saleable, or in much demand: (A:) or that is easy of sale when offered, by reason of her excellence: (T:) or simply, that is easy of sale, or in much demand: (S:) as though, by reason of her beauty, or goodliness, and fatness, she sold herself: (Ksh in ii. 15:) contr. of kaAsidapN: (S, * TA:) the pl. of tAjrp is tawaAjiru. (T, A.) You say also, Ealayoka biAls~ilaEi Alt~awaAjiri (tropical:) [Keep thou to the commodities] that are saleable, or in much demand. (A.) And huwa EalaY A^akorami taAjirapK (assumed tropical:) He is upon a most noble horse. (K.)

A^aroDN mutojarapN * [in the TA, matojirapN, but this is wrong,] A land in which traffic, merchandise, or commerce, is practised; (S, L, K;) and to which people go for the purpose of practising the same: (K:) pl. mataAjiru. (TA.)

div2.head: Quasi tjh
div2.entryFree:
1 tajaha jhy tjh tjp , aor.
1a2a3a , (AZ, K, art. wjh,) inf. n. tajohN; (AZ, TA, in that art.;) or, as As says, tajuha, with damm; (TA in that art.;) i. q. tawaj~aha and waj~aha (K in that art.) and Ait~ajaha. (K in art. tjh.) See art. wjh.

tujaAha tjAh tjAp (S, Msb, K, in art. wjh) and tijaAha (S, K, in that art.) and tajaAha (K in that art.) i. q. wujaAha, (S, Msb, K, in that art.,) which is seldom used; the w being generally changed into t. (Msb, ibid.)

taHot Ht tHt is the contr. of fawoq: (Msb, K:) and Alt~aHotu [signifying The location that is beneath, below, or under,] is opposed to Alfawoqu, and is used in relation to that which is separate from another thing; AlA^asofalu being used in relation to that which is united with [or a part of] another thing. (Kull.) Sometimes, (K,) taHot is an adv. n., (Msb, K,) having a vague signification, its meaning not being clear unless it is prefixed to another word, as in the phrase h`*aA taHota h`*aA [This is beneath, below, or under, this]. (Msb.) And sometimes, it is a simple noun; (K;) in which case, [not having the article Al,] it is indecl., with dammeh for its termination, (K, and I'Ak p. 204,) provided that the noun to which it should be prefixed is suppressed, and the meaning of this is intended to be understood, but not the word itself; (I'Ak ubi suprà;) as in mino taHotu [Beneath, below, or under]; (K;) and in the saying,
A^aqabN mino taHotu EariyDN mino Ealu
[Lean beneath; broad above]: otherwise, it is decl.; (I'Ak ibid.;) as in tajoriy mino taHotihaA AlA^anohaAru [Rivers running beneath them]; (Kur ii. 23, &c.;) i.e., beneath their trees, (Bd, Jel,) and their pavilions. (Jel.) [You say also, fulaAnN taHota A^amori fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) Such a one is under the command, rule, or authority, of such a one. And fulaAnN taHotahu fulaAnapu (assumed tropical:) Such a one has as his wife such a woman: see an ex. in a verse cited voce A_i*aA. The dim. is ↓ tuHayot: you say, h`daA tuHayota h`*aA, and mino tuHayoti h`*aA, This is a little beneath, below, or under, this.] ― -b2- Alt~aHotu is also the sing. of Alt~uHuwtu, (IAth, TA,) which latter [in the CK erroneously written Alt~uHutu] signifies The low, base, vile, or ignoble, persons. (A, IAth, K.) It is said in a trad., laA taquwmu Als~aAEapu Hat~aY taZohara Alt~uHuwtu wa taholika AlwuEuwlu, i. e. [The hour of resurrection will not come until] the low, or ignoble, persons [shall prevail], and the noble persons [shall perish]: (A, IAth, TA:) or, as some say, until the treasures that are beneath the earth appear. (TA.) And in another trad. it is said that among the signs of the resurrection shall be this: A^ano yaEoluw Alt~uHuwtu AlwuEuwla That the weak of mankind shall have ascendency over the strong. (TA.)

taHotaAniY~N Ht tHtAnY tHtAny [Of, or relating to, the location that is beneath, below, or under; inferior; lower;] rel. n. of taHot, like as fawoqaAniY~N is of fawoq: A and n being very often added in the rel. n. (TA.) [tuHayot dim. of taHot, q. v.]

4 AtHfhu bihi AtHfh bh AtHfh bp [He presented him with it; or gave it to him as a tuHofap, q. v.]: (S, Msb:) and AtHfhu tuHofapF [He made a present to him; or gave him a tuHofap; and so AtHfhu alone, as in an ex. cited voce A^atofaHa]: (K, TA:) i. q. A^aTorafahu bituHofapK [which properly means He presented him with a novel, or rare, and pleasing present; or a gift not given to any one before; or a gift of which he (the recipient) did not possess the like, and which pleased him]: and ↓ Ait~aHafahu signifies the same as A^atoHafahu. (TA.)
8 Ait~aHafahu A^tHf A^tHfh AtHfh AtHfp tHfY : see above. [Perhaps originally AiwotaHafahu: see what follows.]

tuHofapN Hf Hfy tHfh tHfp and tuHafapN (S, Msb, K, &c.) i. q. bir~N [as meaning A gratuitous gift, or favour; or a bounty, or benefit]; and laTafN [meaning a present; i. e. a thing sent to another in token of courtesy or honour]; (K;) in some copies of the K, luTof; (TA;) [i. e.] AltHfp signifies maA A^atoHafota bihi Alr~ajula mina Albir~i waAll~aTafi; (S;) or [simply] maA A^atoHafota bihi gayoraka: (Msb:) and a Turofap [which properly signifies a gift not given to any one before; or of which the recipient did not possess the like, and which pleases him;] (K, TA;) of fruit, and of sweet-smelling flowers: (TA:) [it generally means simply a present; or a rare, or pleasing, or rare and pleasing, present:] pl. tuHafN. (S, K.) Accord. to some, it is originally wuHofapN: (K, TA:) Az says that its t is originally w: (Msb:) and tawaH~afa is quasi-pass. of A^atoHafahu: (Lth, TA:) so that it should be mentioned in art. wHf: (K, TA:) being like tuhamapN and tuxamapN &c. (TA.) It is said in a trad., tuHofapu AlS~aAy^imi Ald~uhonu wa Almijomaru [The pleasing present for the faster is oil, and aloes-wood or the like]; i. e., these dispel from him the grievousness and distress occasioned by the fasting. (TA.) And in another, respecting dates, tuHofapu Alkabiyri waSumotapu AlS~agiyri [i. e. The date is the pleasing gift for the big, or full-grown, or old, and the quieter of the little one, or child]. (TA.) And in another, tuHofapu Almuw^omini Almawotu [The boon for the believer is death]. (TA.)
taHiyna HAn tHyn tHynn wHY : see arts. Hyn and lyt.

1 tax~a tx wxY , (JK, S, L, K,) aor.
taxi3a , (JK, L,) inf. n. tuxuwxN, (JK, L, and so in a copy of the S,) or tuxuwxapN, (K, and so in a copy of the S,) or both, (TA,) It (dough) became sour: (JK, S, L, K:) it became soft by reason of too much water: and in like manner, clay, or mud, so that one could not plaster with it. (L.) Also, said of dough, It became leavened; or mature. (JK.)

4 Atx~hu Atxh Atxp
He made it sour; namely, dough: (JK, S, L, K:) he made it soft by putting into it too much water; namely, dough: and in like manner, clay, or mud, so that he could not plaster with it. (L.)

tax~N tx wxY
Sour dough: (JK, S, A, L, K:) such as is soft by reason of too much water. (L.) ― -b2- Also Dregs of sesame-grain from which the oil has been expressed; (JK, L, K;) also called kusobN. (TA.)

taAx~N tAx
Having no desire for food [app. by reason of acidity in the stomach]. (JK, K.)

taxotN tx txt txtp
A repository in which clothes are kept; (K;) [a chest for clothes; a wardrobe: pl. tuxuwtN:] a Persian word sometimes used by the Arabs. (IDrd.) ― -b2- [The following significations of the word seem to be post-classical. ― -b3- A throne: a seat: a seat of government: a moveable wooden bench, or sofa: all which are Persian. Hence, taxotarawaAnN, from the Persian, A kind of covered litter, like a palanquin, borne by two camels or horses, one before and the other behind, or by two or four mules. ― -b4- So too taxotapN A board, or plank: likewise of Persian origin. Hence the verb tax~ata He boarded, or planked.]

1 taxi*a * , aor.
taxa*a , inf. n. taxa*N and taxo*N: see 8 in art. Ax*.
8 At~x* * : see 8 in art. Ax*.
Aisotaxa*a * , an irregularly formed verb: see 8 in art. Ax*.
tixoriySN txryS and tixoriySapN (Lth, K) dial. vars. of dixoriySN and dixoriySapN, (Lth,) A baniyqap [or gore] of a garment: arabicized words, from tiyriyzo, (Lth, K, which is Persian. (Lth.)

div2.head: txm and quasi txm
div2.entryFree:
1 taxima txm txmp xm , [originally waxima,] aor.
1a2a3a , (Msb, and K in art. wxm,) inf. n. taxamN; (Msb;) and taxama, aor. i ; (K ubi suprà;) and ↓ Ait~axama ; (Msb, and S and K &c. in art. wxm;) He suffered from indigestion, or heaviness of the stomach arising from food which it was too weak to digest; (Msb in art. wxm;) he suffered from a disease produced by unsuitable [or unwholesome] food, (K and TA in art. wxm,) or by fulness of the stomach: (TA in that art.:) followed by mina AlT~aEaAmi and Eani AlT~aEaAmi. (S and TA in that art.)
3 tAxm tAxm , [inf. n. mutaAxamapN,] It (a land or country) bordered upon, or was conterminous with or to, another land or country. (AHeyth, Mgh, K.)

4 Atxmhu A^txm A^txmh Atxmh Atxmp txm {txm {txmh , (S and K in art. wxm,) originally A^awoxamahu; (S in that art.,) or formed from tuxamapN, in consequence of imagining the t in this word to be radical; (MF;) said of food, It caused him to suffer from tuxamap [or indigestion]. (S and K in art. wxm.)
8 A_i1ota2a3a see 1.

taxomN txm txmp xm The limit, or boundary, (S, Msb,) of any town (S) or land: (S, Msb:) pl. tuxuwmN: (S, Msb:) a poet (Aboo-Keys Ibn-El-Aslat, TA) says,
yaA baniY~a Alt~uxuwmu laA taZolimuwhaA
(Fr, S,) or, as some relate it, ↓ Alt~axuwmu: (TA:) accord. to the former reading, Fr says, the meaning is, [O my sons,] the limits, or boundaries, [misplace ye not them], for he does not say taZolimuwhu: but ISK says, I heard AA say, it is ↓ taxuwm, and the pl. is tuxumN; like SabuwrN and SuburN: (S:) both IAar and ISk say that the sing and pl. are like rasuwlN and rusulN: (Msb:) but the latter mentions also tuxuwmN, with damm, as a pl. form, having no sing.: (TA:) or ↓ taxuwmN signifies a sign, or mark [of a boundary or of a way]: and limits, or boundaries: and is sometimes with ↓ [to the t]: (Mgh:) Lth says that txwm [written without any vowel-sign] signifies a division, or place of division, between two districts and two towns or villages; and the limit, or boundary, of the land of any district and town or village is its txwm: and AHeyth says that this word signifies limits, or boundaries: (TA:) or tuxuwmN, with damm, signifies a sign, or mark, and a limit, or boundary, that is a division between two lands; and is of the fem. gender: and the pl. is tuxuwmN also, and tuxumN: (K:) this app. means that these are pls. of tuxuwmN; but the former is a word that is used as a sing. and as a pl.; and the latter is pl. of taxuwmN, like as SuburN is of SabuwrN, and gufurN of gafuwrN: (TA:) or (as ISk says, TA) the sing. is ↓ tuxomN and taxomN (K) and ↓ taxuwmapN: (AHn, S, * K:) accord. to A'Obeyd, the Arabic linguists say ↓ taxuwmN, like SabuwrN, making it fem. and sing.; but the people of Syria say tuxuwmN, with damm to the t, making it pl., and the sing. is taxomN: accord. to IB, one says ↓ taxuwmN and tuxuwmN, and zabuwrN and zubuwrN, and Ea*uwbN and Eu*uwbN; and no fourth instance of the kind is known; [but see Ea*uwbN;] and the Basrees pronounce it with damm [to the t], and the Koofees with fet-h. (TA.) It is said in a trad., maloEuwnN mano gay~ara tuxuwma AlA^aroDi, meaning, accord. to A'Obeyd, [Cursed is he who alters] the limits, or boundaries, of land; and the signs, or marks, of the way: or, as some say, the limits, or boundaries, of the sacred territory. (TA.) And AjEl hm~k txwmFA, [or rather AijoEalo liham~ika ↓ taxuwmFA,] means (tropical:) [Set thou to thy purpose] a limit, to which go thou, and pass not beyond it. (TA.) And huwa Tay~ibu Alt~uxuwmi (assumed tropical:) He is good in respect of ancestry, or origin: (JK:) or in respect of natural dispositions; or, as some relate the saying, ↓ Alt~axuwmi. (TA.) tuxuwmN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A state, or condition, that one desires [app. as the limit of his wish]. (IAar, Sh, K.)
tuxomN txm txmp xm : see taxomN.

tuxamapN txm txmh txmp xm , (Msb in the present art., and S and K in art. wxm,) originally wuxomapN, (Msb, and S in art. wxm,) and tuxomapN, (Msb, and S and K in art. wxm,) the latter vulgar, (S in art. wxm,) but occurring in poetry, (S and K in that art.,) Indigestion, or heaviness of the stomach arising from food which it is too weak to digest; (Msb in art. wxm;) a disease produced by unsuitable [or unwholesome] food, (K and TA in that art.,) or by fulness of the stomach: (TA ibid.:) pl. tuxamaAtN (S and K ibid.) and tuxamN. (Msb, and S and K in art. wxm.)
taxuwmN txm txwm : see taxomN, in seven places.
tuxuwmN txm txwm pl. of taxomN, which see throughout: and also used as a sing.
taxuwmapN txm txwmh txwmp : see taxomN.

TaEaAmN matoxamapN TEAm mtxmh TEAm mtxmp , (JK, and S and K in art. wxm,) originally mawoxabapN, (S in art. wxm,) Food that causes one to suffer from tuxamap [or indigestion]. (JK, and K in art. wxm.)

mutaAximN mtAxm
Conterminous to a land (liA^aroDK). (Mgh.) You say also, huwa mutaAximiY He is my neighbour, his house, or tent, adjoining mine. (TA in art. jmd .)

1 tar~a rA^Y tr wrY , (T, M, A, K,) aor.
atira and
atura , (M, K,) the latter irregular, (TA,) inf. n. tar~N and turuwrN, (M, K,) It (a bone, M, K, or anything, M,) became severed, separated, or cut off, (T, M, K,) by a blow, or stroke [of a sword &c.]. (M, A.) And tar~ato yaduhu, inf. n. turuwrN, His arm, or hand, became cut off; (M;) and in like manner, any member: (TA:) or fell off; as also Tar~ato. (S in art. Tr.) ― -b2- tar~ati Aln~awaApu, (S, M, A,) aor.
atira , (S, M,) and
atura , (S,) inf. n. turuwrN, (T, M,) The date-stone leaped, (T, M,) or went forth, (S, A,) from the [mess called] Hayos [in the process of kneading], (T,) or from the stone with which it was to be broken. (S, A.) ― -b3- tar~a Eano qawomihi He was, or became, apart, or separated, from his people. (As, T.) ― -b4- tar~a Eano baladihi He was, or became, or went, far from his country, or town. (S, M, K.) -A2- tar~a, (M,) aor.
atira , (TA,) inf. n. tar~N, (K,) He (an ostrich) ejected what was in his belly. (M, K.) ― -b2- tar~a bisaloHihi, aor.
atura and
atira , He ejected his excrement. (AA, T.) ― -b3- See also 4, in two places. -A3- tar~a, (T, M, K,) sec. pers. tarirota, (S,) aor.
atara , (T, M,) and [sec. pers. tararota, aor.]
atira , (M,) [and app. sec. pers. tarurota, aor.
atura ,] inf. n. [of tarirota or tararota] tar~N and [of tararota] turuwrN (M, K) and [of tarurota] taraArapN, [which last is the most common,] (Lth, T, S, M, K,) He was, or became, plump: (T in explanation of the first verb:) or his body became plump, and his bones full of moisture: (Lth, T, M, K:) or he became fat, soft, thin-skinned, and plump. (S.) ― -b2- And tar~a, aor.
atira , He was, or became, relaxed, or flaccid, from impatience or some other cause. (T. [See taAr~u.])

4 Atr~ A^tr Atr wtr ; (T, S, M, A, K;) and ↓ tar~a, (IDrd, M, K,) inf. n. tar~N; (IDrd, M;) or the former only; (M;) He cut off (T, S, M, K) a man's arm, or hand, by a blow, or stroke, (T, S, M, A,) of a sword; (T, S, A;) made it to fall off: (S:) and in like manner, any member: (M:) as also ATr~ and ATn~. (T.) ― -b2- And the former, (S, A, TA,) or ↓ the latter, (M, as in the TT,) He (a boy) made the piece of wood called qulap to fly away [by striking it] with the miqolaA='. (T, S, * M, * A, * TA.) ― -b3- Atr~hu qawomuhu His people separated him from themselves. (As, T.) ― -b4- Atr~hu AlqaDaA='u Fate drove him far away from his country, or town. (S, M, K.)

R. Q. 1 tarotarahu trtrh trtrp , inf. n. tarotarapN, He moved, put in motion, put into a state of commotion, agitated, or shook, him, or it: (S, M, K:) he shook him vehemently: (M:) he seized his (a man's) arms, or hands, and shook him: (Lth, T:) he shook him (a drunken man) violently, and ordered him to breath in his face, that he might know what he had drunk; (AA, T, K;) as also talotalahu, and mazomazahu: (TA:) or tarotarapN and talotalapN and mazomazapN all signify the act of shaking, agitating, or putting in motion, vehemently. (Mgh.)

R. Q. 2 tatarotara ttrtr
He became moved, put in motion, put into a state of commotion, agitated, or shaken. (S, K.)
tar~N rA^Y tr wrY : see taAr~N: -A2- and tur~N.

tur~N rA^Y tr wrY The string, or line, which is extended upon, or against, a building, (As, S, M,) and according to which one builds, called in Arabic the A_imaAm; (As, M;) the string, or line, by which a building is proportioned: (As, T, M, K:) a Persian word, (T, M,) arabicized; (M;) not Arabic: (IAar:) it is called in Arabic the miTomar. (As, T.) A man, when angry, says to another, laA^uqiyman~aka EalaY Altur~i (tropical:) [I will assuredly make thee to conform to the rule of right behaviour]. (Lth, T, S, A.) -A2- I. q.
A^aSolN: (IAar, T, K:) so in the saying, laA^aDoTar~an~aka A_ilaY tur~ika wa quHaAHika [I will assuredly impel thee, or drive thee, against thy will, to the utmost point to which thou canst go, or be brought or reduced: or constrain thee to do thine utmost]: (IAar, T, and L in art. qH: see quHaAHN:) [accord. to ISd,] laA^aDoTar~an~aka A_ilaY tur~ika means A_ilaY majohuwdika [i. e. I will assuredly make thee to have recourse to thine utmost effort, or endeavour]. (M. [In the K, the signification of Almajohuwdu is erroneously assigned to ↓ Alt~ar~u. See also the saying laA^ulojiy^an~aka A_ilaY qur~i qaraArika explained voce qaraArN.]) tur~ay An arm, or a hand, cut off. (K.)

taraAtiru trAtr [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Great, or formidable, or terrible, things or events or affairs: (S:) distresses, afflictions, or calamities; (M, A, K;) such as are in war. (A.)

taAr~N tAr A man apart, or separate, from his people. (As, T.) -A2- Plump (Lth, T, S, A) in body, (Lth, T,) and having the bones full of moisture; (Lth, T, A;) fat, soft, thin-skinned, and plump: (S, TA:) applied to a youth: fem. with p, applied to a girl; (A, TA;) meaning [plump &c.: or] beautiful and foolish and soft or weak. (T.) You say, gulaAmN taAr~N TaAr~N [A boy that is plump, and with bones full of moisture, whose mustache is growing forth]. (A.) And qaSabapN taAr~apN [A bone of the kind called qSbp full of moisture]. (A.) ― -b2- Relaxed, or flaccid, by reason of impatience (jazaE T) or hunger (jawoE K) [or the contrary (see A^atar~a $aYo'K, below,)] or some other cause: (T, K:) so says Abu-l-'Abbás.
