tafaha , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. tafahN, (JK, Msb, K, TA,) or tafohN, (Mgh, CK,) and tufuwhN (K) and tafaAhapN, (Msb, TA,) or this last is a mistake; (Mgh;) and tafaha, aor.
tafiha , inf. n. tufuwhN; (JK;) It (a thing, JK, Mgh, Msb) was, or became, paltry, sorry, mean, contemptible, or inconsiderable; (JK, S, Mgh, Msb;) and little, or small, in quantity or number. (JK, S, K.) ― -b2- tafiha, aor.
tafaha , inf. n. tufuwhN, He (a man) was, or became, stupid, or foolish. (JK, K.) And tafihato nafosuhu His mind became weak. (JK.) ― -b3- tafaha, aor.
tafuha ; and tafiha, aor.
tafaha ; He, or it, was, or became, lean, or meagre; syn. gav~a. (K.) It is said in a trad. (S, K) of Ibn-Mes'ood, (K,) AlquroA=nu laA yatofahu walaA yata$~aAnu, (S, K, [in the CK, erroneously, yutofahu and yuta$An~u, and in some copies of the K, for the latter is put yntAn,]) i. e. laA yagiv~u wa laA yaxolaqu (assumed tropical:) [The Kur-án will not become meagre, nor will it become worn out]: (K: [in the CK, erroneously, lA yugav~u w lA yuxolaqu:]) it is implied by the context in the S, that lA ytfh means will not become paltry, or mean: lAyt$An~ means will not become worn out by reason of much repetition; from $an~u signifying “ a wornout water-skin. ” (TA.)
4 Atfh fiY EaTaAy^ihi * [He was paltry, sorry, mean, or niggardly, in his gift;] he made his gift little, or small. (TA.)

tafihN fAh tf tfh tfp wfY : see taAfihN. ― -b2- Also Insipid; tasteless; and so ↓ taAfihN. (KL.) You say A^aToEimapN tafihapN Kinds of food having no taste of sweetness, or of sourness, or of bitterness; and some include bread and flesh-meat among these. (K.)

taAfihN tAfh tAfp (S, Mgh, Msb, KL, TA) and ↓ tafihN (Mgh, KL, TA) applied to a thing, (JK, Mgh, Msb,) and the former to a man also, (TA,) Paltry, sorry, mean, contemptible, or inconsiderable: (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, KL, TA:) and little, or small, in quantity or number. (JK, S, TA, and KL in explanation of the former.) ― -b2- taAfihu AlEaqoli A man having little sense, or intellect; (TA;) stupid, or foolish. (JK.) ― -b3- See also tafihN. ― -b4- taAfihN also signifies Afflicted, or distressed, by reason of disease and fatigue. (JK.)
mutaf~ahapN mtfhh mtfhp ; (JK, TA;) so in the handwriting of Sgh; in the K, mutofahapN; (TA;) Easy, submissive, or tractable; applied to a she-camel. (JK, K.)

tiqodapN A^qAd qAd qd qdA qdy tqdh tqdp wqd (JK, S, L, K) and taqodapN (Hr, L, K) and taqidapN (JK, L) Coriander-seed; syn. kuzobarapN. (IAar, JK, S, L, K.) ― -b2- And Caraway-seed; syn. karawoyaA='. (IAar, Th, L, K.)
2 taq~anuwA A^aroDahumo * , (JK, K,) inf. n. tatoqiyna, (K,) They watered their land with thick, or muddy, water, [or water containing tiqon,] (JK, * K,) in order that it might become good. (K.)

4 Atqnhu A^tqn A^tqnh A^tqnnh Atqnh Atqnp , (K,) inf. n. A_itoqaAnN, (JK, S,) i. q. A^aHokamahu [He made it, or rendered it, (namely, a thing, JK, or an affair, S and K,) firm, stable, strong, solid, compact, sound, or free from defect or imperfection, by the exercise of skill; he made it firmly, strongly, solidly, compactly, so that it was firmly and closely joined or knit together, soundly, thoroughly, skilfully, judiciously, or well; he so constructed, constituted, established, settled, arranged, did, performed, or executed, it; he put it into a firm, solid, sound, or good, state, or on a firm, solid, sound, or good, footing]. (JK, S, K.) [And Atqn lahu signifies the same as Atqnhu: or he exercised, or possessed, the skill requisite for it; namely, an affair.] Al~a*iy A^atoqana kul~a $~aYo'K, in the Kur xxvii. 90, means Who hath created everything firmly, strongly, solidly, &c., (A^aHokama xaloqahu,) and made it, fashioned it, or disposed it, in the fit, proper, or right, manner. (Bd.) [You say also, Atqn Eilomahu, meaning He made his knowledge sound; or made himself thoroughly learned.] And Atqn Eanohu He knew it, or learned it, (namely, a tradition [&c.],) soundly, thoroughly, or well, from him. (TA in art. *br.)

tiqonN qnA qnY tAq tqn The rusaAbap of water, (JK, Mgh, K,) in a rivulet or in the channel of a torrent, (K,) in the [season called] rabiyE; (Lth, JK, Mgh;) i. e., (Mgh,) [its sediment, or] the thick matter that is borne by it [and that sinks to the bottom; used for improving land]: (Lth, JK, Mgh:) and (K) the turonuwq of a well (Mgh, K) and of the channel of a torrent; i. e., the slime, mixed with black, or black and fetid, mud; accord. to the Jámi' of El-Ghooree. (Mgh.) ― -b2- A thing by means of which one subsists, and makes good, or improves, the performance, or execution, or management, of an affair; as iron, and other things, of the jawaAhir [i. e. precious stones, or native ores,] of the earth: and anything by means of which a thing is made good, or improved, is called its tiqon. (TA.) ― -b3- A skilful man: (JK, S, K:) pl. A^atoqaAnN. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence, probably,] tiqonN [or Aibonu tiqonK] is also the name [or surname] of a certain man proverbial for his excellence in shooting. (S, K. [In the latter it is implied that this name or surname is Alt~iqonu.]) The rájiz says,
yaramiY bihaA A^aromaY mini A@boni tiqoni
[One more skilled in shooting than Ibn-Tikn shoots it]. (S.) ― -b5- Nature, or natural disposition. (JK, S, K.) You say, AlfaSaAHapu mino tiqonihi Chasteness of speech, or eloquence, is [a quality] of his nature. (S.)

div2.n: Quasi tqY: or, accord. to some, tqw
div2.head: Quasi tqY: or, accord. to some, tqw
div2.entryFree:
1 taqaY tqY tqy wqY , aor.
1a2i3a (T, S, K, in art. wqY) and
1a2a3a , (T, TA,) or taqiYa, aor.
1a2a3a , (Msb, [but the correctness of this I greatly doubt, unless, as appears to be the case, it is meant to be understood as an intrans. verb,]) inf. n. taqoYN, (S and TA in art. tqY, [which art. I find in only one copy of the S,]) or tuqFY, (K,) or tuqaApN, (Msb, and also mentioned in the TA,) of which tuqFY is pl., or coll. n., (Kzz, IB, Msb,) and taqiy~apN (K) and tiqaA='N; (Lh, K;) and ↓ Aitaq~aY, (T, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. Ait~iqaA='N (Msb) and [quasi-inf. n.] taqiy~apN and tuqaApN; (S, art. wqY;) He feared God: (S and TA in art. tqY: all else that follows is from art. wqY except where reference is made to another art.:) or he was cautious of a thing; guarded, or was on his guard, against it; prepared, prepared himself, or was in a state of preparation, against it; or feared it: (K:) or he looked forward to a thing, and guarded against it, sought to avoid it, or was cautious of it. (T, TA.) [For other explanations of the latter verb, which apply also to the former, see art. wqY.] ↓ Ait~aqaY is originally AiwotaqaY; (T, S;) then AiytaqaY; then Ait~aqaY; and when this came to be much in use, they imagined the t to be a radical part of the word, and made the word AitaqaY, aor. yataqiY, with fet-h to the t in each case, and without teshdeed; and not finding any analogue to it in their language, they said taqaY, aor. yatoqiY, like qaDaY, aor. yaqoDiY: (S:) or, as is said in the T, they suppressed the t, and the Ait~aqaY changed into t, in Ait~aqaY, and said taqaY, aor. yatoqiY. (TA.) A poet says, (namely, Khufáf Ibn-Nudbeh, TA,)
jalaAhaA AlS~ayoqaluwna faA^axolaSuwhaA
xifaAfFA kul~uhaA yatoqiY biA^avori
or, as some read it, yataqiY, with the t movent, but without teshdeed; (S;) and this latter, accord.
to IB, is the right reading. (TA.) [See this verse explained in art. Avr.] IB adds that Aboo-Sa'eed [app. meaning As] disallowed taqaY, aor. yatoqiY, inf. n. taqoYN; saying that it would require the imperative to be Aitoqi, which is not said; and this, he states, is right: [for] J says that the imperative used is taqi [Fear thou, or beware thou, &c.], as in taqi A@ll~`hi [Fear thou God]; and to a woman, taqiY; formed from the verb AitaqaY, without tesh-deed, by the suppression of the A. (TA.)

4 maA AatoqaAhu lil~`hi mA AtqAh ll`h mA AtqAh ll`p (S, TA) How great is his reverential, or pious, fear of God! (TA.) ― -b2- mA AtqAhu is also said of a saddle, as meaning How good is it for not galling the back! (TA.)
8 A_i1ota2a3a see 1, in two places; and see also art. wqY.
tuqFY tqY tqy wqY : see taqowaY.

tuqaApN tqAh tqAp tqY : see taqowaY, in two places. ― -b2- In the phrase in the Kur [iii. 27], A_il~aA A^ano tat~aquwA minohumo tuqaApF, it may be an inf. n. [so that the meaning may be Unless ye fear from them with a great fearing (see 1)]: or it may be a pl. [app. of taqiY~N, like as kumaApN is pl. of kamiY~N, so that the meaning may be unless ye fear from them, being fearful]: but it is better to regard it as an inf. n. because another reading is taqiy~apF. (M, TA.)

taqiY~N tqY tqy wqY , applied to a man, (Msb, K, TA,) i. q. waqiY~N (TA) and mut~aqK (S) [Fearing; cautious; &c.: (see 1:) and particularly having a reverential, or pious, fear of God: or simply pious: or one who preserves, or guards, himself, accord. to some, exceedingly, or extraordinarily, from sin, either of commission or of omission: (see 8 in art. wqY:)] accord. to IDrd, one who preserves, or guards, himself from punishment [in the world to come], and from acts of disobedience, by righteous conduct: from waqayotu nafosiY: said by the grammarians to be originally waquwYN; then, taquwYN: or, accord. to Aboo-Bekr, [originally] of the measure faEiylN, as is indicated by the first of its pls. mentioned below: but he who says that it is [originally] of the measure faEuwlN says that it has that pl. because it has become like a word [originally] of the measure faEiylN: (TA:) or righteous, virtuous, just, or honest; (Msb in art. tqY;) contr. of faAjirN: (idem in art. br:) pl. A^atoqiyaA='u (Msb in art. tqY, and K) and tuqawaA='u, (K,) which is extr., and of a class disallowed by Sb, (TA,) [and app. also tuqaApN, q. v. suprà.]
taqiy~apN tqy tqyh tqyp wqY : see what next follows.

taqowaY A^qwY qwY qwy tqw tqwY tqwy , or taqowFY, accord. to different readings in the Kur ix. 110, (Bd,) [of which readings the former is the more common,] is originally taqoyaA, (K,) [or taqoyFA,] or [rather waqoyaA, or waqoyFA, and then] waqowaY, of the measure faEolaY, from waqayotu, (ISd, TA,) or, accord. to MF, the right opinion is that it is [waqowFY,] of the measure faEowalN, (TA,) and is thus transformed in order to make a distinction between the subst. and the epithet such as xazoyaA and SadoyaA: (K:) it is a subst. from Ait~aqaY or waqaY; (Msb, K;) [and signifies Fear; caution; &c.: (see 1:) and particularly reverential, or pious, fear of God: or simply piety: or the preservation, or guarding, of oneself, accord. to some, exceedingly, or extraordinarily, from sin, either of commission or of omission: or the preservation, or guarding, of oneself from punishment in the world to come, and from acts of disobedience, by righteous conduct: or righteousness, virtue, justice, or honesty: (see taqiY~N:) its explanations in relation to religion are many and various, but are all resolvable into fear of God, or of sin; or the preservation, or guarding, of oneself from sin:] and ↓ taqiy~apN and ↓ tuqaApN are syn. with each other (S) and with taqoway, (Msb,) and are used as inf. ns. of Ait~aqaY: (S:) and ↓ tuqFY [also] is syn. with taqoway; (S;) or it is pl. of ↓ tuqaApN, or a coll. n., (Kzz, IB, Msb,) like as TulFY is of TulaApN, (Kzz, IB,) and as ruTabN is of ruTabapN. (Msb.) waA=taAhumo taqowaAhumo, in the Kur xlvii. 19, means And hath explained to them, (Bd,) or suggested to them, (Jel, TA,) what they should fear, or that from which they should preserve themselves: (Bd, Jel, TA:) or hath aided them to practise their taqowaY: (Bd:) or hath given them the recompense of their tqwY. (Bd, TA.) And huwa A^aholu Alt~aqowaY, in the Kur lxxiv. last verse, means He is entitled, or worthy, to be feared; or to be reverentially, or piously, feared. (Bd, Jel, K.)
huwa A^atoqaY mino fulaAnK * [He is more fearing, or cautious, &c., than such a one; more reverentially, or piously, fearful of God; or more pious; &c.;] he has more taqowaY than such a one. (TA.)

10 Asttk~ Alt~ik~apa Asttk Altkh Asttk Altkp , (IDrd, K,) or biAlt~ik~api, (Msb,) He inserted the tik~ap in [the double upper border of] the drawers, or trousers. (IDrd, Msb, K.) You say also, huwa yasotatiku biAlHariyri He makes use of a tik~ap of silk. (A.)

tik~apN tk tkh tkp wkY The band [that is inserted in the double upper border] of the drawers, or trousers; (IDrd, K;) [generally, a strip of cotton, which is often embroidered at each end; sometimes, of net-work; and] sometimes, of silk: (A:) IDrd thinks it to be an adventitious word, though used in ancient times; (TA;) and IAmb says, I think it to be arabicized: (Msb:) pl. tikakN. (S, Msb, K.)

mitak~u mAt mtk mttk The thing by means of which the tik~ap is inserted in [the double upper border of] the drawers, or trousers. (TA.) [It is generally a slender piece of wood, having at one end a loop through which a portion of the tk~p is passed.]

div2.head: Quasi tkA^
div2.entryFree: takiy^a * &c.: see art. wkA^.

div2.head: Quasi tkl
div2.entryFree:
1 takila Ealayohi tkl Elyh tkl Elyp , aor.
1a2a3a , a dial. var. of Ait~akala. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K) See art. wkl; where, also, see tukalapN, &c.

1 tal~ahu A^lhY lhA lhY lhy tl tlh tlp wlh wly , (T, S, * M, Msb, K,) aor.
talu3a , inf. n. tal~N, (M, Msb,) He prostrated him, or threw him down; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) [as some say,] upon the tal~: (TA:) or he threw him down (M, K, TA) upon his taliyl, i. e., (TA,) upon his neck, and his cheek: (M, K TA:) but the former is the more approved; and thus it is explained as used in the phrase watal~ahu lilojabiyni [in the Kur xxxvii. 103], (M,) and he prostrated him, or threw him down, (Aboo-Is-hák, T, S, Bd,) upon his side, so that the side of his forehead fell upon the ground; (Bd;) or upon his mouth; (Katá- deh, T;) or upon his face. (Bd.) And tal~a Aln~aAqapa He made the she-camel to lie down upon her breast. (TA.) ― -b2- He threw it upon the ground: said of any corporeal thing. (M.) ― -b3- tal~a, aor.
talu3a (IAar, T, K) and
tali3a , (K,) [the latter anomalous in this case, and doubtful,] also signifies He poured (IAar, T, K, TA) into the hand of another. (TA.) And tal~a Al$~aYo'a fiY yadihi He gave, or delivered, the thing to him: (M, K *:) or he threw, or put, the thing into his hand. (K.) The Prophet says, bayonaA A^anaA naAy^imN A^utiytu bimafaAtiyHi xazaAy^ini AlA^aroDi fatul~ato fiY yadiY, i. e. [While I was sleeping, I had the keys of the treasures of the earth brought to me,] and they were poured into my hand: (IAar, T, M:) or were thrown, or put, into my hand. (IAmb, M.) ― -b4- Also, (K,) inf. n. tal~N, (M,) He lowered, or let down, the rope into the well, (M, K,) with the hand, on the occasion of drawing water. (M.) ― -b5- sawo'K ↓ tal~ahu bitil~api, [aor.
talu3a , accord. to rule,] He charged him, or upbraided him, with an evil, or a foul, thing. (Th, M, K.) -A2- tal~a, aor.
tali3a (IAar, T, M, K) and
talu3a , (K,) [the latter anomalous in this case, and doubtful,] He was, or became, prostrated, or thrown down; (M, K) he fell, or fell down. (IAar, T, M, K.) -A3- tal~a jabiynuhu, (M, K,) aor.
tali3a (T, M, K) and
talu3a , (K,) [the latter anomalous in this case also, and doubtful,] inf. n. tal~N, (T, M,) The side of his forehead sweated, or exuded sweat. (M, K.) And in like manner the verb is used in relation to a wateringtrough. (Lh, M.) -A4- talilot is an imitative sequent to Dalilot. (M.)

4 Atl~ AlmaAy^iEa *
He made the fluid, or liquid, to drop, or fall in drops. (K.)

R. Q. 1 talotalahu tltlh tltlp , (S,) inf. n. talotalapN, (M, K,) He moved him, agitated him, shook him, put him into a state of motion or commotion; (S, M, K;) or did so vehemently: (S, K, and Mgh in art. tr:) he shook him, or shook him violently, (namely, a drinker,) and ordered him to breathe in his face, that he might know whether he had drunk [wine or the like], or not; (TA in this art. and art. tr;) as also tarotarahu, and mazomazahu. (TA in the latter art.) ― -b2- talotalapN also signifies Hard journeying: and rough, or severe, or vehement, driving. (K.) You say, talotala Alr~ajulu The man was rough, or severe, or vehement, in his driving. (M.) -A2- talotalapu bahoraA='a is [The tribe of] Bahrà's pronouncing the t of
tafoEaluwna with kesr; (M, K;) saying tifoEaluwna, and ti$ohaduwna, and the like. (M.)

tal~N tl wly , accord. to Lth, [and accord. to general present usage,] A mound, or hill, of dust, or earth, [or rubbish,] pressed together, not natural: but this is a mistake [if meant as an explanation of the proper application], for with the Arabs it signifies a natural hill: En-Nadr says that it is of the smaller sort of A_ikaAm [pl. of A^akamapN]; it is of the height of a house, or tent, and the breadth of its back is about ten cubits; it is smaller than the A^akamap, has fewer stones, gives growth to nothing good, and its stones are compacted together exactly like those of the A^akamap: (T:) [the mound, or artificial hill, above mentioned, is what is meant by its being said,] the tal~ of dust, or earth, is well known: and the word signifies also a heap of sand: (M, K:*) in both of these senses from Alt~al~u signifying “ the throwing upon the ground ” anything of a corporeal kind: (M:) also a hill (M, K, TA) overtopping what is adjacent to it: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^atolaAlN (M, TA) and A^atul~N (TA) and [of mult.] tilaAlN (T, S, Msb, K) and tuluwlN. (TA.) -A2- Also A pillow: pl. A^atolaAlN, which is extr.: or the pl. signifies certain sorts of cloths, or of garments: (K, TA:) or, as some say, of pillows. (TA.)

tal~apN A^lhY lhA lhY lhy tl tlh tlp wlh wly [inf. n. un. of 1, by Golius erroneously written tul~apN, and wrongly explained by him,] A single act of pouring [&c.]. (T, K.) ― -b2- A single act of lying upon the side. (K.) -A2- See also talotalapN.

til~apN A^lhY lhA lhY lhy tl tlh tlp wlh wly
A mode, or manner, of lying upon the side. (Fr, K.) ― -b2- Sluggishness, laziness, or indolence. (Fr, T, K.) ― -b3- A state, or condition. (S, M, K) You say, huwa bitil~api sawo'K He is in an evil state or condition; like as you say bibiyoy^api sw': (S:) and baAta bitil~api sawo'K He passed the night in an evil state or condition. (M.) ― -b4- A thing; as in the saying, tal~ahu bitil~api sawo'K [explained above]: see 1. (Th, M, K.) -A2- I. q. bil~apN, (T, M,) or balalN, as also ↓ talalN: (K:) Abu-s-Semeyda' says that til~apN and bil~apN and talalN and tal~apN are all one [i. e. Moisture]. (T.) One says, [app. to a person suspected of having drunk wine or the like,] maA h`*ihi Alt~il~apu bifiyka i. e. Albal~apu [What is this moisture in thy mouth?]. (T, M.)
talalN tll : see til~apN.
Alt~alaAl AltlAl tl in the phrase huwa AlD~alaAlu bonu Alt~alaAli is an imitative sequent. (S, K.)

taliylN tlyl
Prostrated, or thrown down; as also ↓ matoluwlN: (IAar, T, M, K:) [pl. of the former tal~aY, like as SaroEaY is pl. of SariyEN, and qatolaY of qatiylN, &c.; as in the phrase] qawomN tal~aY A company of men prostrated, or thrown down. (M, K.) -A2- The neck: (T, M, K:) and the cheek: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^atil~apN and [of mult.] tululN and talaAy^ilu. (M, K.) You say, lahu taliylN kaji*oEi Als~aHuwqi [He has a neck like the trunk of the tall palm-tree]. (TA.)
Alt~alaAlapu AltlAlh AltlAlp is an imitative sequent to AlD~alaAlapu. (T, * S, M, * K.)

talotalapN tltlh tltlp inf. n. of R. Q. 1 [q. v.]. ― -b2- Also Hardship, difficulty, distress, or adversity: (M, K:) pl. talaAtilu, (TA,) signifying hardships, difficulties, &c. (Aboo-Turáb, T, S, M.) -A2- A drinking-vessel that is made of the envelope (qiyqaA='ap, S, or qiyqaA=', M and K) of the spadix of a palm-tree; (S, M, K;) so called because what it contains is poured into the throat; (T;) as also ↓ tal~apN: (M, K:) it is said that nabiy* is drunk with it. (TA.)
tal~N tl wly is an imitative sequent to DaAl~N. (T, * S, M, * K.)

matal~N mtl
A place of prostrating. (TA.)

matal~N mtl [as a subst.] A thing with which one prostrates: (M, K:) and hence a spear: (Msb:) and [as an epithet], applied to a spear, with which one prostrates: (T, * S, M:) or, applied to a spear, erect; or even and erect. (K.) ― -b2- Strong; (S, M, K;) applied to a man and to a camel (M, K, TA) &c. (TA.) ― -b3- A man erect in prayer: (T, M, K:) so accord. to Lth, who cites the saying,
rijaAlN yutil~uwna AlS~alaApa qiyaAmu
but this is a mistake; for yutil~uwna is from tal~aY, and means, who make prayer to follow prayer. (T.)
mutal~ilN mtll One who prostrates much, or often; who does so by twisting his leg with the leg of another. (T.)
matoluwlN mtlwl : see taliylN.
Q. 4 AitolaA^ab~a * : &c.: see art. tlb.

talaAna A^lAn tl tlAn
i. q. A@loA=na [At the present time; now]: (As, K:) the t is added, as in taHiyna. (A'Obeyd &c.) See art. Ayn.

Q. Q. 4 AitolaA^ab~a * , (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. Aitoliy^obaAbN, (S, K,) It (a thing, M, or an affair, or a case, S, K, or a road, A) was, or became, uniform or undeviating, (A,) right, or rightly directed or ordered: (S, M, A, K:) or (M) it (a thing, M, or a road, S, K) was, or became, extended, (Fr, T, S, M, A, K,) and right, direct, even, or uniform: (S, M, K: *) or (M) it (a thing, M) was, or became, set up, or erect. (M, A, K.) You say, mar~uwA faA@nolaA^ab~a bihimu AlT~ariyqu [They went along, and the road was, or became, uniform, &c., with them; i. e., their road was, or became, uniform, &c.]. (A.) And AtlA^b~ A^amoruhumo [Their affair, or case, was, or became, right, or rightly directed or ordered]. (A.) ― -b2- He (an ass) raised his breast and head. (S, K.) ― -b3- This verb and its derivatives are mentioned in the [T and] S and K in the present art.; but they are held by [ISd and] IB to be radically quadriliteral. (TA.)

talobN lAb lb lbY tlb
Loss; or the state of being lost; or perdition. (A, K.) One says, tab~FA lahu talobFA, (Lth, T,) or tab~FA lahu watalobFA [which may be rendered May God decree loss and perdition to him]. (K.)
tulaA^obiybapN * a subst. (S, M, K) from AitolaA^ab~a; (Fr, T, S, M, K;) [signifying The state of being uniform or undeviating, right, &c.;] like TumaA^oniynapN [from AiTomaA^an~a]. (TA.)

tawolabN twlb , perfectly decl. [when used as a proper name as well as when used as an appellative], because it is of the measure fawoEalN; (Sb, S;) for we judge its t to be a radical, and its w to be augmentative, because fawoEal is more common [as the measure of a noun] than tafoEal; (M;) but accord. to Suh, the t is a substitute for w, and, if so, it should be mentioned in art. wlb; (TA;) A young ass; syn. jaHo$N: (S, K:) or the foal of a wild ass, when he has completed a year. (M.) And A^um~u tawolab is an appellation given to The she-ass. (S.) ― -b2- The former is sometimes metaphorically applied to (tropical:) A [young] man: (M:) or a boy. (S.)

mutolay^ib~N * [Uniform or undeviating,] right, or rightly directed or ordered [&c.: see the verb]; as also musolaHib~N. (Asudot;, T) Also applied to a rule, (A, TA,) as meaning Uniform, undeviating, or of general application; uniformly, or constantly, obtaining. (TA.)
mataAlibu mtAlb [app. pl. of matolabN or matolibN] The places where a wound causes death; syn. maqaAtilu. (IAar, T.)

div2.head: Quasi tlj
div2.entryFree: A^atolaja * : and tawolajN: see art. wlj.

1 talada ld tld wld , aor.
talida (T, S, M, Msb, K;) and
taluda , (T, sudot;, M, K,) inf. n. tuluwdN; (S, M, Msb, K;) [and ↓ Ait~alada; (see Ham p. 699;)] It (property, consisting of camels or the like, syn. maAlN, T, S, M, &c.) was, or became, old, or long-possessed; (Msb;) such as is termed tilaAd. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- talada fulaAnN EinodanaA Such a one was born of parents at our abode, or home. (L.) ― -b3- And talada, (T, S, M, K,) aor.
taluda , (M, K,) inf. n. as above; (T, L;) and talida, aor.
talada ; (K;) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (As, T, S, M, K,) fiY baniY fulaAnK among the sons of such a one, (S,) and bayonahumo among them, (M,) and bimakaAnK in a place. (As, T, L.) -A2- See also 2.

2 tl~d ld tld wld , (IAar, T, K,) inf. n. tatoliydN; (K;) or ↓ talada; (so in the L as on the authority of IAar, and accord. to Lh as is said in the TA;) i. q. jamaEa and manaEa [app. as meaning He collected and defended property]; (IAar, T, L, K;) said of a man. (IAar, T, L.)

4 Atld Atld , (T, S, L.) and Atld maAlFA, (T, M, Msb, K,) He got, obtained, or acquired, (Ait~axa*a,) property [such as is termed tilaAd, as is implied in the T and M and K]: (T, S, L, Msb:) or he possessed
property such as is termed tilaAd. (So accord. to the explanation of the act. part. n., q. v., in the Mgh.)
8 A_it~alada see 1.
talodN ld tld wld : see tilaAdN, in two places.
tulodN ld tld wld : see tilaAdN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The young one of an eagle. (M, K.)
taladN ld tld wld : see tilaAdN: ― -b2- and taliydN.

tilaAdN tlAd , applied to maAl [i. e. property, consisting of camels or the like], (T, S, M, &c.,) Old, or long-possessed; as also ↓ taAlidN and ↓ taliydN, (Mgh, Msb,) both of these meaning old, original, property, (A,) and ↓ mutoladN: (L:) or original, old, or long-possessed, born at one's own abode, or home; as also ↓ taAlidN and ↓ A_itolaAdN: (S:) contr. of TaArifN (S, A, Mgh, Msb) and TariyfN: (Mgh, Msb:) or born at the owner's abode, or house; or that brings forth there; (M, K;) as also ↓ taAlidN (K) and ↓ talodN and ↓ tulodN, (M, K,) and ↓ taladN (K) and ↓ tilydN and ↓ A_itolaAdN, (M, K,) like A_isonaAmN, (M, [in the CK written AatolA^ad, and so accord. to the MS,]) and ↓ mutoladN;]) (M, K; [written in a copy of the M mutal~d;]) wherefore, [i. e. because of the meaning,] Yaakoob judges that the t is a substitute for w; [as is said to be the case in the S;] but this is not a valid decision; for, were it so, the word in some of its variations would be reduced to its original: (M:) or any old, or long-possessed, property, (T, M, L,) consisting of animals &c., (M, L,) inherited from parents; (T, M, L;) as also ↓ taAlidN (T, L) and ↓ taliydN and ↓ mutoladN (T, M, L [the last written in a copy of the T mNtolidN, and in a copy of the M mutal~d,]) and ↓ talodN and ↓ tulodN and ↓ A_itolaAdN, as above: (M:) or slaves, or pasturing beasts, that breed at one's own abode, or home, and become old, or long possessed: (ISh, as related by Sh:) or that which you yourself breed, or rear. (As, T.) [See also taliydN, below. ― -b2- Hence,] hun~a mino tilaAdiY, said by a man, (namely, Ibn-Mes'ood, M,) in reference to certain chapters (suwar) of the Kur-án, meaning (tropical:) They are of those which I acquired (or learned, L) long ago from the Kur-án: (S, M, L:) thus saying, he likened them to the property, or camels &c., called tilaAdN. (M, L.) ― -b3- [Az says,] I heard a man of Mekkeh say, tilaAdiYbimak~apa, i. e. miylaAdiY [app. meaning My birth was in Mekkeh]. (T.)

taliydN tlyd : see tilaAdN, in three places. ― -b2- Also That which is born at the abode, or home, of another than thyself, and which, while young, thou afterwards purchasest, and which remains with thee: (As, T.) or one who is born in a foreign country, and is carried away while young to the territory of the Arabs: (Mgh:) or one who is born in a foreign country, and then brought away while young, and who grows up in the territory of the Muslims; (S, K;) as also ↓ taladN: (K:) or i. q. muwal~adN and muwal~adapN, [masc. and fem.,] meaning one that is born at thine own abode, or home: (ISh, T: [see also tilaAdN:]) or one who has parents at thine own abode, or home; whereas muwal~adN signifies one who has only one parent there: (Mgh, from the Tekmileh [of the 'Eyn]:) the fem. is with p; (S;) signifying a female slave who is born in a foreign country, and is carried away, and grows up in the territory of the Arabs: (Kt, T:) or a female slave whose father and family and all her relations are in one country and who is herself in another: (ISh, L in art. wld:) or a female slave born the property of a people with whom are her parents: (L in art. wld:) or a female slave inherited by her owner; if born at his own abode, or home, [of a mother already belonging to him,] she is called waliydapN: (T, L:) you say rajulN taliydN; pl. tuladaA='u: and AimoraA^apN taliydN [and taliydapN]; pl. talaAy^idu (Lh, M, L) and tuludN. (Lh, L.) It is related in a trad. of Shureyh, that a man purchased a female slave, and the two parties made it a condition that she should be a muwal~adap; but the purchaser found her to be a taliydap, and therefore returned her: (S, Mgh:) a muwal~adap is like a tilaAd, i. e. born at thine own abode, or home; (S;) or born in the territory of the Muslims. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also, metaphorically, (tropical:) A child, absolutely. (Har p. 317.)
taAlidN tAld : see tilaAdN, in four places. ― -b2- taAlidN baAlidN: see art. bld.
A_itolaAdN AtlAd , by some written A^atolaAdN: see tilaAdN, in three places.

mutoladN mtld , applied to maAl, (S, Msb,) pass. part. n. of 4: (Msb:) see tilaAdN, in three places. ― -b2- [Hence,] xuluqN mutoladN, (M, L, TA,) in the K, mutal~adN, said to be like muEaZ~amN, but this is a mistake, (TA,) [and in the CK, xaloqN is erroneously put for xuluqN,] (assumed tropical:) An old, or a long-possessed, natural disposition, or quality. (M, L, K.) IAar cites as an ex. this verse:
maA *aA ruziynaA minoki A^am~a maEobadi
mino saEapi AlHilomi wa xuloqK mutolad
[app. meaning What has been experienced from us, on thy part, Umm-Maabad, of largeness of forbearance, and of long-possessed good natural dispositions, or qualities? ruziynaA seems to be here used for ruziy^onaA; or the latter may be the correct reading]. (M, L.)

mutolidN mtld [act. part. n. of 4:] A possessor of property such as is termed tilaAd: and hence, ― -b2- A first owner or proprietor; as the weaver of a piece of cloth, and the man who delivers his she-camel [and is owner of her young one]. (Mgh.)

taloEapN tlEh tlEp
High, or elevated, land or ground: (AO, S, K:) and low, or depressed, land or ground: (AO, S, Msb, K:) thus bearing two contr. significations, (S, K,) accord. to AO: (S:) or it has not these significations, but means a water-course from the upper part of a valley to its lower part; therefore sometimes its upper part is described [by this name], and sometimes its lower part; (IAar, IB, TA:) or it has the second of the significations above, (Msb, K,) and the first, (K,) and signifies also a water-course (Msb, K) from the upper part of a valley: (Msb:) and also, (K,) or, accord. to IDrd, (TA,) the wide part of the mouth of a valley: and a high, or an elevated, piece of land or ground: (IDrd, K:) sometimes, says IDrd, it has this last application; but the former is the original signification: (TA:) it is also said to signify high, or elevated, and rugged, land or ground, in which the torrent goes to and fro, and from which it then pours to another tlEp, lower than it; and which is fertile in plants, or herbage: (L, TA:) or a water-course from the higher part of the ground to the bottom of a valley: (AA, S:) pl. tilaAEN (AA, S, Msb, K) and talaEaAtN: (K:) and, (K,) or, accord. to Sh, (TA,) tilaAEN signifies water-course flowing from acclivities and the [eminences termed] nijaAf and the mountains, until they pour into the valley: (Sh, K:) to which Sh adds, the tlEp of the mountain being formed by the water's coming and furrowing and excavating it until it escapes from it: (TA:) but tlAE are nowhere except [the word A_il~Aa has been dropped in the CK] in the SaHaAraY [or deserts]; (Sh, K;) and sometimes a tlEp comes from a distance of five leagues (faraAsix) to the valley; and when it flows from the mountains, and falls into the SHArY [or deserts], it excavates in them what resembles a moat: when it becomes so large as to be like the half, or two thirds, of the valley, it is termed mayovaA='u: (Sh, TA:) taloEapN is also said to be like rHbp [i. e. raHabapN or raHobapN, app. as meaning the part of a valley in which its water flows into it from its two sides]; and the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] is said to be taloEN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., fayajiYo'u maTarN laA yamotaniEu minohu *anabu taloEapK [And a rain will come, in consequence of which the end of a water-course will not be impeded]: meaning to denote its abundance, and that no place will be exempt from it. (TA.) And in a prov., fulaAnN laA yamonaEu *anaba taloEapK [Such a one will not impede the end of a water-course]: (K, * TA:) applied to the abject and contemptible. (K.) And in another, (ISh,) laA A^aviqu bisayoli taloEatka [I do not, or will not, trust in the flow of thy water-course]: applied to him in whom one does not trust: (ISh, K:) i. e. I do not, or will not, trust in what thou sayest, and what thou adducest: characterizing the person as a liar. (ISh.) And in another, (IAar,) maA A^axaAfu A_il~aA mino sayoli taloEatiY [I fear not save from the flow of my water-course]: i. e., from the sons of my uncle, and my relations: (IAar, K:) for he who descends the water-course is in danger: if the torrent come, it sweeps him away. (IAar.)

1 talifa A^lfY lAf lf tlf , (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
talafa , (K,) inf. n. talafN, (Lth, T, S, M, &c.,) He, or it, (a thing, Lth, T, S, Msb, of any kind, Lth, T,) perished, passed away, was not, was no more, became nonexistent or annihilated; or went away, no one knew whither; or became in a bad, or corrupt, state; became corrupted, vitiated, marred, or spoiled; [in this sense the verb is often used in the present
day;] or he died: syn. halaka; (M, K;) and of the inf. n., EaTabN (Lth, T,) and halaAkN. (Lth, T, S.) [See also talafN, below.]

4 Atlfhu A^tlf A^tlfh Atlfh Atlfp tlf
He caused him, or it, (a thing, S, Msb, or property, M,) to perish, pass away, or be no ore; or to go away, no one knew whither; or to become corrupted, vitiated, marred, or spoiled: (S, M:) or he made it (his property, T) to pass away, come to an end, come to nought, or be exhausted; destroyed, wasted, consumed, or exhausted, it; (T, K;) by prodigality. (T.) [See an ex. in a verse of Ibn-Mukbil cited voce A^axolafa.] ― -b2- El-Farezdak says,
waqawomK kiraAmK qado naqalonaA A_ilayohimu
qiraAhumo faA^atolafonaA AlmanaAyaA waA^atolafuwA
(so in the T and L,) or
waA^aDoyaAfi layolK qado naqalonaA qiraAhumu
A_ilayohimo waA^atolafonaA AlmanaAyaA waA^atolafuwA
(so in some copies of the K,) or qado balagonaA qiraAhumu, (so in other copies of the K and in the TA,) or qd faEalonaA qrAhm, (so in the O,) i. e., [accord. to the different readings, How many a generous company of men has there been, or how many guests of the night have there been, to whom we have brought their entertainment, and] we have found the fates to be destructive, (T, K, *) and they have found them to be so: (T:) it is like the phrase A^atayonaA fulaAnFA faA^aboxalonaAhu and A^ajoban~aAhu: (TA:) or we found the fates to destroy us, and they found them to destroy them: or we made the fates to be destruction to them, and they made them to be destruction to us: (ISk, K:) he means, we engaged with them in vehement fight, and slew them. (TA.)

talafN A^lfY lAf lf tlf
A perishing, passing away, &c. [See 1.] (Lth, T, S, &c.) It is said in a trad., (TA,) A_in~a mina Alqarafi Alt~alafu (T, TA) Verily, from the being near to pestilence, or epidemic disease, there results death, or perdition. (T.) And in a prov., Als~alafu talafN [The paying for a thing beforehand is a cause of perishing to one's property]. (TA.) And one says, *ahabato nafosuhu talafFA and TalafFA, (S, K,) both meaning the same, (S,) His blood went for nothing, or as a thing of no account, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct. (S, K.)
talifN A^lfY lAf lf tlf , (M,) or ↓ taAlifN, (Msb, TA,) part. n. of 1, Perishing, &c.; (M, Msb, * TA;) as also ↓ talofaAnN, which is post-classical. (TA.)

talofapN A^lfY lAf lf tlf tlfh tlfp
A [hill, mountain, or mass of rock, such as is termed] haDobap, difficult of access, so that he who attempts it fears perdition, or death. (ElHejeree, M.)
talofaAnN lf tlfAn : see talifN.
taAlfN A^lf tA^lf tAlf : see talifN.

matolafN mtlf
A place of perishing or perdition: (K:) a [desert such as is termed] mafaAzap; (S, K;) because most of those who traverse it perish; and so ↓ matolafapN; (TA;) or the latter signifies a [desert such as is termed] qafor: (M:) the pl. of the former [or of both] is mataAlifu. (TA.)

rajulN mutolifN limaAlihi rjl mtlf lmAlh rjl mtlf lmAlp , (Msb,) or ↓ rajulN mitolafN, and ↓ mitolaAfN, (M,) A man who destroys, or wastes, his property: (M:) or the last has an intensive signification, (Msb,) meaning who destroys, or wastes, his property much. (S.) You say also, rajulN muxolifN mutolifN, (K, and Har p. 312,) or ↓ mixolafN mitolafN, (TA in art. xlf,) and mixolaAfN, ↓ mitolaAfN, (K, and Har ubi suprà,) meaning A man of courage and liberality, who makes what he takes as spoil, of the property of his enemies, to supply the place of that which he consumes by expenditure to satisfy the claims of his friends. (Har ubi suprà.)
mitolafN mtlf : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
matolafapN mtlf mtlfh mtlfp : see matolafN. ― -b2- Also A deep hollow, cavity, or pit, where one looks down upon destruction. (M.)
mitolaAfN mtlAf : see mutolifN, in two places.
matoluwfN mtlwf [i. q. munokarN, q. v.; i. e.] contr. of maEoruwfN: but this is post-classical. (TA.)
tiloka *`lk lAk lk tl tlk wly and taloka and taAlika: see art. tA.

Q. 1 taloma*a *
He was, or became, a tilomiy* [or disciple, &c.], lifulaAnK to such a one. (TA, passim.)

tilomiy*N *
A disciple; a pupil; a learner: or a special servant of a teacher: so says 'Abd-El- Kádir El-Baghdádee, who composed a treatise solely on this word: (MF, TA:) or simply a servant; a follower; a dependant: pl. talaAmiy*u (L, TA) [and talaAmi*apN].

1 talaA tl tlA
He followed; or went, or walked, behind, or after. (IAar, T.) You say, talawotuhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
taluwa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tuluw~N (S, M, Msb, K) and talowN, (Er-Rághib, MF,) I followed him or it; or went, or walked, behind, or after, him or it; (S, M, Msb, K;) namely, a man [&c.]; (S, Msb;) immediately, or without intervention; and sometimes it means bodily [or in reality]; and sometimes, virtually, or in effect: (Er-Rághib:) and so talayotuhu; (K;) and ↓ tal~ayotuhu, (As, * T, * K,) inf. n. tatoliyapN. (K.) The phrase, in the Kur xci. 2, waAlqamari A_i*aA talaAhaA means By the moon when its rising follows the rising thereof; i. e., the rising of the sun; at the beginning of the lunar month: (Bd:) or, when it follows in rising the setting thereof, (Bd, Jel,) on the night of the full moon: (Bd:) or, when it follows it in becoming round, and in fullness of light; (M, * Bd;) i. e., when it follows it in the way of imitation, and in respect of rank; for the moon borrows its light of the sun, and is to it in the place of a successor. (Er-Rághib.) Here, Ks pronounced tlAhA with imáleh, [either because talayotu is a dial. var. of talawotu, or] because, although it has w for its last radical letter, it occurs with words that may be so pronounced, namely, yago$aAhaA and banaAhaA. (M.) ― -b2- talawotu AlA^ibila (tropical:) I drove, or brought, or gathered, the camels together, from their several quarters: because the driver follows the driven. (A, TA.) ― -b3- huwa yatoluw fulaAnFA He imitates such a one, and follows what he does; he follows him in action. (T.) ― -b4- talaA, (T,) first pers. talawotu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
taluwa , (T,) inf. n. tilaAwapN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) He read, or perused, or he recited, (T, M, K,) the Kur-án, (S, M, Msb, K,) or any discourse, or piece of language: (M, K:) or he followed it, (I'Ab, T, S, * M,) and did according to it; (I'Ab, Mujáhid, T;) namely, the Scripture: (I'Ab, Mujáhid, T, M:) or the inf. n. specially signifies the following God's revealed Scriptures, sometimes by reading, or perusing, or by reciting, and sometimes by conforming therewith [as well as by reading, &c., but not otherwise, for] every tilaAwap is qiraA='ap, but the reverse is not the case. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [You say also, talaA Ealayohi He recited, or related, to him a narrative &c.: see Kur v. 30, &c.] And fulaAnN yatoluw EalaY fulaAnK, and yaquwlu Ealayohi, Such a one lies, or says what is false, against such a one. (TA.) waA@t~abaEuwA maA tatoluwAl$~ayaATiynu, in the Kur ii. 96, means [And they followed] what the devils related, or rehearsed, ('Atà, T,) or spoke; (A'Obeyd, T;) or, what the devils of the Jinn, or of mankind, or of both, read, or recited, or what they followed, of the writings of enchantment: (Bd:) some here read ↓ tutal~iY. (T.) Hence the saying, laA darayota walaA talayota: (T:) or, accord. to Yoo, it is ↓ wlA A^atolayota: (T, S:) and others say that it is wlA A@y^otalayota, from A^alawotu. (T. [See these three readings explained in the latter part of the first paragraph of art. Alw.]) -A2- He remained behind, or held back. (IAar, ISk, T.) You say, talaA baEoda qawomihi He held back, or lagged behind, after his people, or company, and remained. (TA.) And talawotuhu, (AZ, A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K,) and talawotu Eanohu, (AZ, T, M, K,) aor.
taluwa , (AZ, T,) inf. n. tuluw~N, (AZ, T, M,) I left him, and held back from going with him: (AZ, T:) I held back from him, or from aiding him, and left him: (AZ, A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K:) thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (K.) -A3- He bought a tilow, meaning the young one of a mule. (IAar, T, K.) -A4- taliyato liY mino Haq~iY taliy~apN, and tulaAwapN, aor.
talawa , (ISk, S,) inf. n. talFA, (TA,) There remained to me, of my right, or due, a remainder. (ISk, S.) And taliyato liY Einodahu taliy~apN There remained to me, with him, or there remained owing to me by him, a remainder. (As, T.) And taliYa mina Al$~ahori ka*aA, (M, K,) inf. n. talFA, (M,) There remained, of the month, such a portion. (M, K.)

2 tal~awa see 1, in two places. ― -b2- huwa yutal~aY baqiy~apa HaAjatihi He demands, and seeks to obtain, the remainder of that which he wants. (T.) ― -b3- tl~Y SalaAtahu, (T, M, K,) inf. n. tatoliyapN, (K,) He made his prayer to be followed by other prayer: (T:) or he made his prescribed prayer to be followed by supererogatory prayer. (Sh, M, K.) ― -b4- tl~Yi, inf. n. as above, [is also said to signify] He stood erect for
prayer. (TA. [But see mital~N, in art. tl.] ― -b5- Also He accomplished, or fulfilled, his vow. (IAar, M, K.) ― -b6- And He was at the last gasp. (AZ, S, M, K.) -A2- See also 4.

3 tAlAhu tAlAh tAlAp , inf. n. mutaAlaApN, i. q. raAsalahu [meaning, fiY AlginaA='i, i. e. He relieved him, or aided him, in singing, by taking up the strain when the latter was unable to prolong his voice sufficiently for the accomplishing of the cadence; or he did so with a high voice: see mutaAlK, below]. (TA.)

4 A^atolayotuhu A_iy~aAhu *
I made him to follow him; or, it to follow it. (M, K.) Hence, (TA,) AtlAhu A@ll~`hu A^aTofaAlFA God made him, or may God make him, to have little children following him. (S, TA.) And A^atolato She (a camel) had her young one following her: (S, K:) whence the saying, laA darayota walaA A^atolayota; accord. to Yoo: (S:) but see 1, where two other readings are mentioned, with a reference to the explanations. ― -b2- [Hence also,] A^atolayotuhu I preceded him, outwent him, outstripped him, or got before him. (S.) And maA zilotu A^atoluwhu Hat~aY A^atolayotuhu I ceased not to follow him until I became before him. (S.) ― -b3- A^atolayotu Haq~iY Einodahu I left a remainder of my due with him. (S, K.) And A^atolayotu Einodahu taly~apF I left with him a remainder (T, M) of a thing, or of a debt, or of a needful thing. (M.) ― -b4- A^atolayotuhu EalaY fulaAnK I referred him, or turned him over, for the payment of what was owing to him, to such a one, transferring the responsibility for the debt to the latter. (T, S, * K. *) ― -b5- AtlAhu *im~apF He gave him a bond, or an obligation, whereby he became responsible for his safety: (S, K:) and AtlAhu alone (T, M, K) signifies the same; (T;) he gave him what is termed talaA=', (M, K,) i. e. *im~apF, (K,) or jiwaArFA, (M, K,) and meaning also an arrow on which was written his (the giver's) name, (K, * TA,) in order that, when he went to a tribe, he might show it to them, and they would not harm him: (TA:) and AtlAhu sahomFA (assumed tropical:) he gave him an arrow whereby to demand protection, (M, K, TA,) in order that he might not be harmed: and AtlAhu naEolFA he gave him a sandal for that purpose: (TA:) and it means (tropical:) he made him his tilow [or follower], and his companion. (TA.) ↓ tl~Y, also, signifies, like A^atolaY, He gave him his bond, or obligation, by which he became responsible for his safety. (TA.)

5 ttl~Y A^tlY tlA ttlY ttly
He sought repeatedly, or in a leisurely manner, or by degrees, (T, S, M, K,) to obtain his right, or due, until he received it fully, or wholly, (T, S,) or to obtain a thing. (M, K.) ― -b2- He collected much wealth. (IAar, T.) ― -b3- tatal~ayotu Haq~iY Einodahu I left with him, or in his possession, somewhat remaining of my right, or due. (IAar, T.) -A2- Somewhat remained of his debt. (IAar, T.)

6 tataAlati AlA^umuwru *
The things, or events, were consecutive; they followed one another. (M, K.) And jaA='ati Alxayolu tataAliyFA The horses, or horsemen, came consecutively. (S.)

10 AsttlAhu Al$~aYo'a *
He, or it, invited him to follow the thing. (M, K.) ― -b2- Aisotatolayotu fulaAnFA I made such a one to follow me. (IAar, T.) ― -b3- And I looked for, expected, awaited, or waited for, such a one. (IAar, T.) -A2- AsttlY fulaAnFA also signifies (tropical:) He sought, or demanded, of such a one, the arrow of protection [called talaA=', q. v.]. (TA.)
talFA tl tlA : see taliy~apN.

tilowN A^lwY lwY lwy tlw
A thing that follows another thing: (K:) and a follower of another man. (TA.) See also tilowu Al$~aYo'i taAlK means That which follows the thing: (S:) and h`*aA tilowu h`*aA This is what follows this. (M.) [Hence,] tilowu Aln~aAqapi The she-camel's young one that follows her: (S:) and tilowN [alone] a ewe's, or she-goat's, (M,) or she-camel's, (K,) young one when weaned, and following the mother; pl. A^atolaA='N; and fem. with p: (M, K:) and the young one of the ass; (M, K;) because he follows his mother: (M:) and the young one of a mule: (IAar, T, K:) and, accord. to En-Nadr, a kid, and a lamb, that has become large in the stomach or belly (Astkr$) and in no need of his mother; fem. with p: (T:) or the fem. signifies a she-kid that has passed beyond the limit of those that are termed A^ajofaAr [pl. of jaforN, q. v.], (M, K,) until she has completed a year [from her birth] and so become a ja*aE. (M.) And a tilowap of sheep or goats is One that is brought forth, or that brings forth, [the verb is tunotaju, which has both of these meanings,] before the Safariy~ap [q. v.]. (S, K.) -A2- Also High, or lofty. (K.) One says, A_in~ahu latilowu AlmiqodaAri Verily he, or it, is high, or lofty, in measure. (TA.)

talaA='N tlA='
A bond, or an obligation, by which one becomes responsible for the safety of another: (S, M, K:) and an arrow upon which the giver writes his name, (M, K, [in the CK, AlmatoliYo is erroneously put for AlmutoliY,]) and which he gives to a man, who, when he goes to a tribe, and shows it to them, passes unmolested: (M:) and, accord. to IAmb, responsibility, or suretiship. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The transfer of a debt, or of a claim, by shifting the responsibility from one person to another. (Z, TA.)
taluw~N A^lwY lwY lwy tlw A man incessantly following: (IAar, M, K:) not mentioned by Yaakoob among the instances of this measure which he has limited; as Hasuw~N and fasuw~N. (M.)
taliY~N tl tlY tly tlyy wly [accord. to the CK, erroneously, tiloYN,] Using many oaths (kaviyru AlA^ayomaAni): and Having much wealth. (IAar, T, K.)

taliy~apN tl tlyh tlyp wly [accord. to the CK, erroneously, tiloyapq,] and ↓ tulaAwapN (ISk, T, S, M, K) and ↓ talFA (M, TA) A remainder (ISk, T, S, M, K) of a thing, (M,) or of a right or due, (ISk, S,) or of a debt, (S, M, K,) and of a thing wanted, (ISk and T in explanation of the second word, and M,) &c. (K.) One says also, *ahabato taliy~apu Al$~abaAbi (tropical:) The remainder of youthfulness, or youthful vigour, departed. (TA.) And fulaAnN taliy~apu AlA^aHoraAri (tropical:) [Such a one is the last remaining of the ingenuous]. (TA.) ― -b2- waqaEa ka*aA taliy~apa ka*aA Such a thing happened after such a thing. (M.)
tulaAwapN tlAwh tlAwp : see taliy~apN.

talaw~aY A^lwY lwY lwy tlw tlwY tlwy
A kind of boat: (M, K:) of the measure faEaw~alN, (M, TA,) or faEalowalN: (TA:) so called because it follows the larger vessel: mentioned by Aboo-'Alee in the Tedhkireh. (M.)
tal~aA='N liloquroA=ni tlA=' llqrA=n One who reads, peruses, or recites, the Kur-án, or who follows it, or acts according to it, much, or often. (Mgh.)

taAlK A^lA tA^l tAl tAly act. part. n. of talaA; Following; going, or walking, behind, or after; [immediately, or without intervention; either in reality, or only in effect; (see 1;)] (T, Msb;) as also ↓ tilowN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Alt~aAliY The fourth of the ten horses that are started together in a race. (TA voce suk~ayot &c., and Ham p. 46.) ― -b3- Also, (Sh, TA voce mijodaHN,) and taAliY Aln~ajomK [meaning The follower of the Pleiades], (Kzw,) the star called Ald~abaraAnu. (Sh, Kzw.) ― -b4- And taAliyaAtu Aln~ujuwmi The last of the stars; [app. the last that are seen in the morningtwilight;] (TA;) as also Alt~awaAliY. (M, TA.) [taAliyaAtN and tawaAl are both pls. of taAliyapN, fem. of taAlK.] ― -b5- Alt~awaAliY also signifies The last of women journeying in vehicles upon camels; (M, K;) and in like manner, of camels. (M.) ― -b6- Also Hinder parts, posteriors, or rumps: and the hinder parts of horses: or (of a horse, M) the tail and hind legs. (M, K.) One says, A_in~ahu laHaviyvu Alt~awaAliY and sariyEu Alt~awaAliY [app. meaning Verily he is quick in the hind legs]. (M.) And the Arabs say, layosa hawaAdiY Alxayoli kaAlt~awaAliY, i. e., The necks of horses are not like their hinder parts. (TA.) ― -b7- faAlt~aAlayAti *ikorFA [in the Kur xxxvii. 3] means And those angels, or angels and others, that recite the praise of God. (M.)

mutolK mtl and mutoliyapN (T, M) A mother, (T,) or a she-camel, and a female wild animal, (M,) having her young one following her: pl. mataAlK. (T, M.) ― -b2- Also, both sings., A she-camel that brings forth in the last portion of the breeding-time: or the latter sing. signifies one that is late in bringing forth; and the former sing. has the first of the meanings explained in this paragraph: (M:) or, as some say, the latter sing. signifies one that has become heavy by pregnancy, so that the head of her fœtus has turned towards the tail and the vulva; a meaning not agreeing with the derivation: (IJ, M:) or, as some say, this word signifies [simply] pregnant: (Ham p. 688:) accord. to El-Báhilee, the pl. signifies she-camels of which some have brought forth, and others have not. (TA.) You say, A_ibiluhumo mataAlK, meaning Their camels have not brought forth until the season called the Sayof, (K, TA,) which is the last part of the breeding-time. (TA.)

mutaAlK mtAl One who relieves, or aids, another, in singing, and in work, by taking up the strain, or the work, when the latter is unable to continue it: (IAar, T:) or one who so relieves, or aids, the singer, with a high voice: (S, TA:) and one who
sings to camels to urge them on, or excite them. (TA.)

musotatolK msttl [act. part. n. of 10, q. v. It is said in the T to have a signification derived from talaA='N in the last of the senses assigned to the latter word above; so that it seems to mean Seeking, or demanding, the transfer of a debt, or claim, or the like, by shifting the responsibility from one person to another].
1 talayotuhu tlyth tlytp : see talawotuhu.
taliY~N tl tlY tly tlyy wly &c.: see art. tlw.

1 tam~a Al$~aYo'u * , (T, S, M, K, &c.,) aor.
tami3a , (T, M, K,) inf. n. tamaAmN, (T, S,) or timaAmN, (M,) or both, and tumaAmN, (K,) and tamaAmapN (M, K) and timaAmapN, (K,) and tm~u and tam~N and tum~N, (M, K,) of which last three forms the first is said to be the most chaste, (TA,) [The thing was, or became, complete, entire, whole, or full; i. e., without, or free from, deficiency: and sometimes, the thing was, or became, consummate, or perfect; which latter signification is more properly expressed by kamala:] accord. to the author of the K, as is shown in art. kml, and accord. to some others, tamaAmN and kamaAlN are syn.; but several authors make a distinction between them: the former is said to signify a thing's being, or becoming, without, or free from, deficiency; and the latter, to signify tmAm and something more, as, for instance, goodliness, and excellence, essential or accidental; though each is sometimes used in the sense of the other: or, as some say, the former necessarily implies previous deficiency; but the latter does not: (MF, TA:) or, accord. to El-Harállee, the latter signifies the attaining to the utmost point, or degree, in every respect: or, as Ibn-El-Kemál says, when one says of a thing kamala, he means that what was desired of it became realized. (TA.) [See also tamaAmN, below.] You say, tam~a xaloquhu [His make, or formation, was, or became, complete, or perfect; he (a child or the like, and a man,) was, or became, fully formed or developed, or complete in his members; and he (a man) was, or became, full-grown]: (TA:) [whence, probably,] tam~a Al$~aYo'u [as meaning] The thing became strong and hard. (Msb.) And tam~a Alqamaru, (T, S, Msb,) or ↓ Atm~, (M, K,) The moon became full, so that it shone brightly. (M, K) And, of her who is pregnant, tam~ato A^ay~aAmu HamolihaA [The days of her gestation became complete]. (S.) ― -b2- tam~a A_ilaY ka*aA He reached, attained, arrived at, or came to, such a thing; as, for instance, eminence or nobility, or the means of acquiring eminence or nobility. (TA.) ― -b3- tam~a A_ilaY mawoDiEi ka*aA, and A_ilayohi ↓ Atm~, He repaired, or betook himself, to, or towards, such a place; he went to it. (Har p. 508.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
fabaAta bijamoEK vum~a tam~a A_ilaY minFY
[which may be rendered And he passed the night in Jema (a name of El-Muzdelifeh): then he repaired, or went, to Minè; there completing the ceremonies of the pilgrimage; wherefore ISd says,] I think that, by tm~, [or rather tm~ AlY mnY,] he means he completed his pilgrimage. (M.) ― -b4- tam~a bihi, and tam~a Ealayohi: see their syn. Atm~hu (4). ― -b5- [Hence,] tam~a Ealayohi He performed it, or executed it; he accomplished it; namely, an affair; a fast; a purpose, or an intention. (Mgh.) ― -b6- And He persevered in it; (Mgh, TA;) as also tamama Ealayohi, without teshdeed, as in the phrase A_ino tamamato EalaY maA A^uriydu [If she persevere in what I desire], occurring in a trad.; but IAth says that the verb here means ↓ tam~amato. (TA.) You say, tam~a EalaY AlA_baA='i He persevered in refusal, or dislike, or disapproval. (Mgh.) -A2- tum~a It was broken. (T.) ― -b2- And i. q. blg [app. buliga, i. e. He was jaded, harassed, distressed, fatigued, or wearied]. (T.)

2 tam~amahu tmm tmmh tmmp : see its syn. Atm~hu; and see also 1, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b2- He, or it, destroyed it; made it to reach its appointed term of duration. (Sh, T, K.) ― -b3- tam~amahumo He gave them the share of their arrow in the game called Almayosir; (IAar, M, K;) i. e. he gave them to eat the flesh which was their share. (M.) Accord. to Lh, Alt~atomiymu in the game called Almysr signifies A man's taking what has remained, so as to complete the shares, or make up their full number, when the players have diminished from the slaughtered camel [by taking their shares]. (T.) ― -b4- t~mm EalaY AljariyHi (tropical:) He hastened and completed the slaughter of the wounded man: or made his slaughter sure, or certain. (M, K, TA.) -A2- t~mm Alkasoru, (M, K,) and ↓ ttm~m, (M, TA,) in the copies of the K, erroneously, tam~a, (TA,) [in the CK, t~mm again,] i. e. [The fracture, or the broken bone, or simply the bone,] cracked, without separating (walamo yabino): or cracked, and then separated. (M, K.) You say, tam~ama Alkasora fatam~ama and ↓ tatam~ama [He, or it, completed the fracture, or cracked the broken bone, or the bone, and it cracked, &c.]. (M.) And ↓ ZalaEa fulaAnN vum~a tatam~ama, i. e. [Such a one limped, or halted, or was slightly lame: then] his lameness became complete by fracture: from tum~a signifying “ it was broken: ” (T:) [or tatam~ama signifies his lameness became complete by an increased fracture, after he had had a fracture with which he was able to walk: this is what is meant by the following loose explanation:] Alt~atam~umu mano kaAna bihi kasorN yamo$iY bihi vum~a A^abat~a fatatam~ama. (K. [In the CK, Aab~ata is here erroneously put for A^abat~a.]) -A3- tm~m Alamawoluwda He hung tamaAy^im, (Th, M,) or a tamiymap, (K,) upon the new-born child, or young infant. (Th, M, K.) ― -b2- tam~amotu Eanohu AlEayona I repelled from him the evil eye by hanging [upon him] the tamiymap. (A, TA.) -A4- tm~m also signifies He became, in the inclination of his mind, (Lth, T, M, K,) and in his opinion, and his place of abode or settlement, (Lth, T, K,) as one of the tribe of Temeem; (Lth, T, M, K;) as also ↓ ttm~m; (K, TA; [in the CK, tm~m again;]) or accord. to analogy it would be ttm~m, like tmD~r and tnz~r. (T.) And He asserted himself to be related to the tribe of Temeem. (M.)
3 mutaAm~pN mtAmh mtAmp [inf. n. of taAm~a] The vying, or contending, with another in completeness, or perfection. (KL.) [You say, tAm~hu He vied, or contended, with him &c.]

4 Atm~ A^tm Atm tAm tm , said of the moon: see 1. ― -b2- Said of a plant, It became tall and full-grown; or became of its full height, and blossomed. (M, K.) ― -b3- A^atam~ato, said of one that is pregnant, She completed the days of her gestation: (S:) or, said of a woman and of a she-camel, (M,) she became near to bringing forth. (M, K.) ― -b4- At~m A_ilaY mawoDiEi ka*aA: see 1. -A2- Atm~ Al$~aYo'a, (S, M, K,) or AlA^amora, (Mgh,) and Atm~ bihi, (M,) inf. n. A_itomaAmN; (TA;) and ↓ tm~mhu, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. tatomiymN and tatim~apN; (T, TA;) and ↓ Asttm~hu; (S, Mgh, K;) and bihi ↓ tam~a, and Ealayohi ↓ tam~a; (M, K;) signify the same; (S Mgh;) i. e. jaEalahu taAm~aA (M in explanation of all but the last, and K in explanation of all that are mentioned therein,) and A^akomalahu (M in explanation of the last) [He made the thing, or the affair, complete, entire, whole, or full; i. e., without, or free from, deficiency; he completed it: and sometimes, he consummated, or perfected, it]. waA^atim~uw AlHaj~a waAlEumorapa, in the Kur [ii. 192], means And perform ye, or accomplish ye, completely, the rites and ceremonies [of the pilgrimage and the minor pilgrimage]; (M, * Bd;) accord. to some: or, as some say, A_itomaAmu AlHaj~i means that the money, or the like, that one expends in performing the pilgrimage should be lawfully obtained, and that one should refrain from doing what God has forbidden. (M.) And faA^atam~ahun~a, in the Kur [ii. 118], means And he performed them, or accomplished them, completely, (Bd, Jel,) and rightly: (Bd:) or he did according to them. (Fr, TA.) -A3- Atm~hu He gave him what are termed timam, pl. of tim~apN, and meaning jizaz [explained below, voce tim~apN], (M, TA,) in order that he might complete therewith his web. (TA.) [In consequence of its being misplaced in the K, this is there made to signify He gave him a tim~, meaning a faA^os or a misoHaAp.]
5 tatam~a3a see 2, in four places.

6 tataAm~uwA ttAmwA
They came, [and also, accord. to Golius, app. on the authority of a gloss in a copy of the KL, they drank,] all of them, and were complete. (S, K.) One says, AijotamaEuwA fatataAm~uwA Ea$arapF [They collected themselves together, and came, all of them, making altogether ten]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., tataAm~ato A_ilayohi qurayo$N, i. e. Kureysh obeyed his call, and came to him, all of them, following one another. (TA.)

10 Asttm~hu Asttmh Asttmp : see 4. ― -b2- Astt~m Aln~iEomapa He asked for the completion of the benefit, or boon, or favour. (M, K.) -A2- He sought, demanded, or requested, of him what are termed tim~m, pl. of tim~apN, and meaning jizaz [explained below, voce tim~apN], (M, TA,) in order that he might complete therewith his web. (TA.) [In consequence of its being misplaced in the K, this is there made to signify He sought, demanded, or requested, of him a tim~, meaning a faA^os or a misoHaAp.]

R. Q. 1 tamotamapN tmtm tmtmh tmtmp is the inf. n. of tamotama, (Msb,) and signifies The reiterating in uttering the letter t: (Mbr, Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán, ” T, S, Msb:) [if so, syn. with taA^otaA^apN:] or the tongue's pronouncing indistinctly, missing the place of the letter, [i. e. the place of its pronunciation in the organs of speech,] and recurring to an utterance like t and m, though this be not distinct: (Lth, T:) or the making the speech [or tongue] to revert [repeatedly] to t and m: (M, K:) or the jabbering, or hurrying in one's speech, so as hardly, or not at all, to make a person understand: (M:) or the uttering in such a manner that one's speech proceeds rapidly to the roof of his mouth. (M, K.)
tam~N tm an inf. n. of 1, in the first of the senses explained above. (M, K.) See tamaAmN, in two places. -A2- See also tim~apN.
tum~N tm an inf. n. of 1, in the first of the senses explained above. (M, K.) See tamaAmN, in two places.

tim~N tm an inf. n. of 1, in the first of the senses explained above. (M, K.) See tamaAmN, in five places: ― -b2- and taAm~N, in three places. -A2- Also i. q. faA^osN [app. here meaning A kind of hoe]: (IAar, T, K:) or i. q. misoHaApN [a spade, or a shovel]: (K:) pl. timamapN (IAar, T,) or timamN. (So in the TA.)
tum~apN A^mAh mAhw tmh tmp : see what next follows, in two places.

tim~apN A^mAh mAhw tmh tmp (M, K) and ↓ tum~apN (TA) [the former written in the CK tam~apN] sings. of timamN (M, K, TA) and tumamN, (K, TA,) or ↓ tamamN, which [ISd says] I think to be a quasi-pl. n., (M,) or ↓ tam~N is the quasipl. n.: (K:) these, i. e. the pls. and quasi-pl. n., signify Shorn crops (jizaz [in the CK jizar, for which Golius appears to have found Hiroz, for he has rendered it by “ amuletum, ” and Freytag has done the same,]) of $aEar [meaning goats' hair], and of camels' hair, and of wool, (M, K, TA,) of that wherewith a woman [or a man] completes her [or his] web: (TA:) and ↓ tum~apN signifies what is given, of wool, or camel's hair, [or goats' hair,] (S, TA, [and mentioned also in the K, but there, by misplacement, made to relate to tim~N instead of tim~apN,]) for a man to complete therewith the weaving of his kisaA='; (S;) as also ↓ tum~aY. (K, * TA.)
tum~aY tmY tmy : see tim~apN.
tamamN tmm : see taAm~N, in four places: -A2- and see also tim~apN.

tamaAmN tmAm (T, S, K) and ↓ timaAmN (M, K) and ↓ tumaAmN (K) inf. ns. of 1, in the first of the senses explained above; (T, S, M, K;) as also ↓ tim~N and ↓ tam~N and ↓ tum~N. (M, K.) [Hence,] ↓ waladatohu litim~K and ↓ litimaAmK and litamaAmK She brought him forth at the completion of formation; (K, TA;) i. e., when his formation was complete: (TA:) [or, at the completion of gestation:] and, accord. to As, waladatohu Alt~amaAma, with the art. Al; not indeterminate, except in poetry. (IB, TA.) And waladato litamaAmK and ↓ litimaAmK [She brought forth at the completion of formation; or, of gestation]. (S.) And A^aloqati Alwalada ligayori tamaAmK and ↓ timaAmK [She cast the child at a period not that of the completion of formation; or, of gestation; i. e., prematurely]. (Msb.) And wulida Almawoluwdu litamaAmK and ↓ litimaAmK [The infant was born at the completion of formation; or, of gestation]. (T, * S.) And wulida Alwaladu litamaAmi AlHamoli and AlHamoli ↓ litimaAmi [The child was born at the completion of gestation]. (Msb.) [These exs., and others following, show that an assertion of IDrd, mentioned in the M, namely, that one says, ↓ wulida AlgulaAmu litim~K and ↓ litimaAmK, and ↓ badoru timaAmK, and that in every other case it is tamaAm, with fet-h, requires consideration.] You say also, badoru tamaAmK and ↓ timaAmK [lit. The full moon of completion]: and ↓ badorN timaAmN [lit. A complete full moon]: all meaning the moon, or a moon, when it is full, so that it shines brightly: (M, K:) and qamarN tamaAmN and ↓ timaAmN A complete, or full, moon. (S.) And layolapu Alt~amaAmi and layolapu tamaAmi Alqamari, with fet-h to the t, (ISh, T,) or ↓, laylapu Alt~imaAmi with kesr, [which seems to be at variance with general usage,] and sometimes with fet-h, (Msb,) [The night of the completion of the moon; i. e.] the night of the full moon; (ISh, T, Msb;) which is the thirteenth night; (ISh, T;) or the fourteenth. (T.) And ↓ layolu Alt~imaAmi, with kesr only, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) thus distinguished from what next precedes, (ISh, T,) as also ↓ layolu timaAmK, and in like manner, layolN ↓ timaAmN (T) and ↓ layolN timaAmiY~N, (T, K,) The longest night of the year; (Lth, T, S;) the longest night of winter; (As, ISh, T, M, K;) that in which our Lord Jesus was born: (As, T:) or each of three nights of which no deficiency is apparent: (Lth, T, M, K:) or the night that is from thirteen to fifteen hours in length: (Aboo-'Amr EshSheybánee, T:) or the night that is twelve hours or more in length: (AA, T, M, K:) and any night that is long, or tedious, to one, and in which one does not sleep, is called ↓ layolapu Alt~imaAmi, or said to be like the night thus called. (IAar, T.) And Al$~ahori ↓ ruy^iYa AlhilaAlu litim~i [The new moon was seen at the completion of the month; showing that another month was commencing]. (T.) And ↓ A^abaY qaAy^iluhaA A_il~aA tim~FA and ↓ tam~FA and ↓ tum~FA, (S, M,) three dial. vars., of which the first is the most chaste, i. e., tamaAmFA [meaning The sayer thereof refused, or did not consent to, aught save completion]; he executed, or accomplished, or kept to, his saying; he did not go back from it. (S, TA.) ― -b2- tamaAmN (with fet-h only, AZ, AAF, M) also signifies The complement of a thing; the supplement thereof; the thing by the addition of which is effected the completion or perfection of a thing; (AZ, T, AAF, M, K;) and so ↓ tamaAmapN (M, K) and ↓ tatim~apN. (T, M, K.) You say, h`*ihi Ald~araAhimu tamaAmu h`*ihi AlmiAy^api, and h*h AlmAy^p ↓ tatim~apu, These dirhems are the complement of this hundred; or, what complete this hundred. (T.) [And ↓ tatim~apu kitaAbK The supplement of, or to, a book.] ― -b3- See also taAm~N, in two places.
tumaAmN tmAm : see tamaAmN, first sentence.
timaAmN tmAm : see tamaAmN, throughout the greater part of the paragraph: ― -b2- and see also taAm~N.

tamiymN tmym
Strong; firm; hard: (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, Msb, K:) or strong in make, or formation: (TA:) or complete, or perfect, in make, or formation, and strong: (M:) applied to a man and to a horse: (M, TA:) fem. with p. (TA.) See also taAm~N. ― -b2- Also Tall; (T;) applied to a man. (TA.) -A2- See also tamiymapN.
tamaAmapN tmAm tmAmh tmAmp : see tamaAmN, near the end of the paragraph.

tumaAmapN tmAm tmAmh tmAmp
A remainder, or remaining portion, (K,) of anything. (TA.)

tamiymapN tmymh tmymp
A kind of amulet (Euw*apN, T, S) which is hung upon a human being; forbidden to be worn: (S:) or a kind of bead: (S, Mgh:) erroneously imagined by some to be the same as maEaA*apN: (El- Kutabee, Mgh:) but as to the maEaA*aAt that are inscribed with something from the Kur-án, or with the names of God, in these there is no harm: (S, Mgh:) a speckled bead, black speckled with white, or the reverse, which is strung upon a thong, and tied to the neck: (M, K:) sing. of tamaAy^imu and [n. un. of] ↓ tamiymN: (T, M, K:) tamaAy^imu signifies certain beads which the Arabs of the desert used to hang upon their children, to repel, as they asserted, the evil eye: (T, Mgh:) or the tamiymap is, accord. to some, a necklace (qilaAdap) upon which are put thongs and amulets (Euwa*): (M:) or a necklace (qilaAdap) of thongs: and is sometimes applied to the amulet (Euw*ap) that is hung upon the necks of children: (T:) but he who makes tmAy^m to signify thongs is in error: El-Farezdak uses the phrase suyuwru Alt~amaAy^imi because they are beads which are perforated, and into which are inserted thongs or strings whereby they are suspended: (T, Mgh:) Az says, I have not found among the Arabs of the desert any difference of opinion respecting the tmymp, as to its being the bead itself: (TA:) but accord. to En-Nakha'ee, the Prophet disapproved of everything hung upon a child or grown person, and said that all such things were tmAy^m: (Mgh:) the tmymp is [said to be] thus called because by it the condition of the child is rendered complete. (Har p. 22.)
timaAmiY~N tmAm tmAmY tmAmy : see tamaAmN.

tamotaAmN tmtAm One whose utterance is such as is termed tamotamapN: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) [see R. Q. 1: accord. to most authorities,] one who reiterates in uttering the letter t: (S, Mgh, Msb:) or, accord. to AZ, one who jabbers, or hurries in his speech, so as not to make another understand: (Mgh, Msb:) fem. with p. (M, K.)

taAm~N tAm [part. n. of 1 in the first of the senses explained above]: (T, M, K, &c.:) Complete, entire, whole, or full; without, or free from, deficiency: and consummate, or perfect: (MF, TA:) as also ↓ tamaAmN, [which see above,] (M, * KL,) [and ↓ timaAmN,
of which see three exs. voce tamaAmN,] and ↓ tim~N, (Kh, T, Har p. 82,) and ↓ tamamN. (TA.) Thus taAm~u Alxaloqi signifies Complete, or perfect, in make, or formation; without any deficiency in his members; applied to a man; (MF, TA;) [and, thus applied, signifying also full-grown, as does, sometimes, taAm~N alone: and likewise applied to a new-born child, meaning fully formed or developed:] and ↓ tamiymN signifies the same, (M, K,) applied to a man and to a horse, (M,) and ↓ tamamN also; and in like manner is used the phrase ↓ xaloqN tamamN [a complete, or perfect, make or formation]. (TA.)

ja*aEN taAm~N * [applied to a goat] signifies That has completed the time in which he is termed ja*aE, and attained to that in which he is termed tayos. (TA.) And ↓ tamamN is applied to a bull, or an ox, That is in the stage of growth next before that in which all his teeth are grown; in which latter stage he is termed EamamN. (L voce EaDobN, on the authority of Et-Táïfee.) You say also kalimapN taAm~apN, and daEowahN taAm~apN; [meaning A perfect, or faultless, sentence, and oath;] using the epithet tAm~p in these instances because of the mention of God therein; for which reason there may not be in aught of either of them any deficiency or defect. (TA.) And ↓ jaEalahu tim~FA i. e. ↓ tamaAmFA [He made it complete, or perfect]. (M.) And ↓ jaEalotuhu laka tim~FA I made it, or have made it, to be thine, or I assigned it, or have assigned it, to thee, completely, or wholly. (T.) ― -b2- [Hence, fiEolN taAm~N meaning A complete, i. e. an attributive, verb: opposed to fiEolN naAqiSN.]
tatim~apN A^tm ttmh ttmp : see tamaAmN, in three places, at the close of the paragraph.
mutam~N mAt mtm mttm The place of cutting, or termination, (munoqaTaE, in the CK munoqaTiE,) of the vein (Eiroq [app. meaning chord]) of the navel. (K.)

mutim~N mAt mtm mttm , applied to one that is pregnant, (S,) or to a woman, (M, TA,) and a she-camel, (M,) That has completed the days of her gestation: (S:) or that is near to bringing forth: (M:) or that is at the point of bringing forth. (TA.)

mutam~imN mtmm One whose arrow wins time after time [in the game called Almayosir], and who feeds the poor with the flesh [of the camel which constitutes the shares] thereof: (M, K:) or who, when players in the game called Almysr have diminished the slaughtered camel [by taking their shares], takes what has remained, so as to complete the shares, or make up their full number. (K. [See 2. In the CK, naqaSa AiyosAra jazuwori Almayosiri is erroneously put for naqaSa A^ayosaArN jazuwra Almayosiri.])

AljahaAlapu Almusotatam~apu AljhAlp Almsttmh AljhAlp Almsttmp
Consummate ignorance: improperly written Almusotatim~apu, though this latter is explainable [as meaning that completes the extent to which it can go, or the like]. (Mgh.)

musotatim~N msttm One who seeks, demands, or requests, wool, or camels' hair, to complete therewith the weaving of his kisaA=': so in a poem of Aboo-Duwád, (S,) where he says,
fahoYa kaAlbayoDi fiY AlA^adaAHiY~i laA yuwo
habu minohaA limusotatim~K EiSaAmu
i. e., And they (referring to certain camels) are, in respect of the care that is taken of them, and in smoothness, like the eggs [in the places where the ostrich has deposited them in the sand]; there may not be found upon them to be given from them, to one who demands a tim~ap, [even so much as] a tie for a water-skin; for they have become fat, and cast their hair. (TA.)

1 tamara A^mAr A^mr mAr mr tmr , (S, M, K, &c.,) aor.
tamura , (M, TA,) or
tamira , (Msb,) inf. n. tamorN; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓ tm~r, (M, K,) inf. n. tatomiyrN; (TA;) and ↓ Atmr; (M, K;) He fed people with, or gave them to eat, tamor [or dried dates]. (S, M, Msb, K.)

2 tm~r A^mAr A^mr mAr mr tmr , inf. n. tatomiyrN, He dried (S, M, K) dates. (S.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He dried flesh-meat: (T, S:) or he cut flesh-meat into small pieces, (M, A, * IAth, K,) like dates, (IAth,) and dried it. (M, A, IAth, K.) It is said in a trad., kaAna laA yaraY biAlt~atomiyri baA^osFA (tropical:) He used not to see any harm in cutting flesh-meat into small pieces, like dates, and drying it: meaning, in a Mohrim's thus preparing flesh-meat for travelling-provision; or in one's drying the flesh of wild animals before the state of ihrám. (IAth.) ― -b3- See also 1: ― -b4- and 4, in two places.

4 Atmr Atmr {y^tmr |tmr
He possessed many, or a large quantity of, tamor [or dried dates]. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- Atmrt Aln~axolapu, (T, M, A, K,) and ↓ tm~rt, (M, K,) The palm-tree bore tamor [or dry dates]: (M, K:) or had ripe dates upon it. (K.) ― -b3- Atmr Alr~uTabu; (T, K;) and ↓ tm~r, inf. n. tatomiyrN; (K;) The ripe dates became in the state in which they are termed tamor. (K.) ― -b4- See also 1.

5 ttm~r ttmr
It (flesh-meat) was cut into strips, or small pieces, and dried. (A.)

tamorN A^mAr A^mr mAr mr tmr , a coll. gen. n.; (S, A;) masc. in one dial. and fem. in another [like other nouns of the same class]; (Msb;) Dates, or the fruit of the palmtree: (M:) or dried dates, like zabiybN as applied to grapes, by general consent of the lexicologists: (Mgh, Msb:) the dates are left upon the palmtree, after they have become ripe, until they are dry, or nearly so, when they are cut, and left in the sun to dry thoroughly; and sometimes, as AHát says, the fruit of the palm-tree is cut when full-grown but unripe, to lighten the tree, or from fear of theft, and left until it becomes tamor: (Msb:) the n. un. is with p: and the pl. of tamorN is tumuwrN and tumoraAnN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) meaning sorts or varieties [of tamor]; for a coll. gen. n. has not a pl. in the proper sense: (S:) and in like manner the dual tamoraAni means two sorts [of tamor]: (Sb cited in the M in art. bsr:) the pl. of tamorapN is tamaraAtN. (S, K.) [See also busorN.] Hence the prov., A^aEoTi A^axaAka tamorapF faA_ino A^abaY fajamorapF [Give thou thy brother a dried date; and if he refuse it, a live coal]. (A, TA.) And Alt~amoru biAls~awiyqi [Dried dates with meal of parched barley or wheat] is another prov., used in allusion to requital. (Lh.) And one says, wajada Einodahu tamorapa AlguraAbi, meaning (tropical:) He found with him, or at his abode, what he approved. (A.) And nafosuhu tamorapN bika*aA (tropical:) His mind is pleased, or agreeably affected, with, or by, such a thing; or consents to such a thing. (A, K. * [Accord. to the TA, it is here like fariHapN; but this seems to be true as to the meaning; not as to the form of the word. See also art. vmr, voce vamirN.]) And daEoniY A_in~a nafosiY gayoru tamorapK (tropical:) [Leave thou me, or let me alone: verily my mind is not pleased, or happy]. (A.) ― -b2- tamorN hinodiY~N [The fruit of the tamarindtree; thus called in the present day;] i. q. HumarN and HawomarN. (K in art. Hmr.)

tamoriY~N A^mr mr tmr tmrY tmry tmryy
One who loves tamor [or dried dates]. (S, A, K.)

tam~aArN A^mAr mArY tmAr
A seller of tamor [or dried dates]. (S, A, K.)

taAmirN A^mr tA^mr tAmr
Possessing tamor [or dried dates]; (S, M, A, Msb;) like laAbinN “ possessing milk: ” (S, Msb:) or taAmirN, (Lh, M, K,) or ↓ mutomirN, (S, A,) signifies possessing many, or a large quantity of, tamor: (Lh, S, M, A, K:) the former of these two words is held by ISd to be a possessive epithet: (TA:) and sometimes it may signify feeding people with, or giving them to eat, tamor. (S, TA.)
taAmuwrN tAmwr and taAmuwrapN and tuwmuwrN and tuwmuriY~N &c.: see art. Amr.
mutomirN mtmr : see taAmirN.

matomuwrN mtmwr
Furnished with tamor [or dried dates] for travelling-provision. (S, K.)

1 tamaka tmk , aor.
tamuka (S, K) and
tamika , (K,) inf. n. tamukN (S, K) and tumuwkN, (K,) It (a camel's hump) was, or became, tall, or long and high: (S, K:) it was, or became, juicy, and compact, (O, K,) and plump. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tamaka fiyhi AlHusonu [app. (assumed tropical:) Beauty became fully developed, or consummate, in him]. (TA.)

4 Atmk sanaAmahu Atmk snAmh Atmk snAmp [It made his (a camel's) hump to become tall, or long and high, or juicy and compact, and plump]; said of the [herbage called] rabiyE. (A, TA.) And Atmk Aln~aAqapa It (herbage) made the she-camel fat. (IDrd, K.)

taAmikN tAm tAmk , applied to a camel's hump, Tall, or long and high: (S, TA:) or high: or juicy, and compact, and plump: (TA:) or a camel's hump, in whatever state it be. (M, K.) ― -b2- A she-camel having a large hump: (ISd, K:) pl. tawaAmiku. (TA.) ― -b3- A high, or lofty, building. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, A_in~ahu lataAmiku AljamaAli [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily he is a person of fully-developed, or consummate, beauty]. (TA.) ― -b5- And $arafuka taAmikN waA_iqobaAluka saAmikN (tropical:) [Thy nobility is lofty, and thy good fortune is high]. (A, TA.)

tam~uwzu tmwz [sometimes written tamuwzu, without tesh-deed,] The [Syrian] month [sacred, in ancient times, to the god of that name, (mentioned in Ezek. viii. 14,) corresponding to July, O. S.,] after HaziyrAnu. (S in art. Hzr.)

1 tan~a biAlmakaAni tn bAlmkAn , [aor., accord. to rule,
tani3a , i. q. tanaA^a,] He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (M.)
3 tAn~ bayonahumaA tAn bynhmA , (K,) inf. n. mutaAn~apN, (TA,) He measured, or compared, them two together. (K.)

4 Atn~ A^tAn A^tn Atn , (K,) inf. n. A_itonaAnN, (TA,) He, or it, was, or became, distant, or remote. (K.) -A2- Atn~hu It (a disease) stunted him, (AZ, IAar, T, S, M, K,) namely, a child, or boy, (IAar, T, S, M, K,) so that he did not attain to the stature of his equals in age, (AZ, T,) or so that he did not attain to full growth. (IAar, T, S, M, K.)
R. Q. 1 tanotana A^ntn nAt ntn tntn tntnn [in the CK tatan~ana] He (a man, IAar, T) left, or deserted, his friends, and associated with others. (IAar, T, K.)
tan~N tn wnY : see tin~N. -A2- See also a poetical citation voce taw~N.
tun~N tn wnY and tun~apN The tunny-fish. (Golius on the authority of Ibn-Beytár; and so in the present day; but the former is a coll. gen. n., and the latter is a n. un.)

tin~N tn wnY
A like; an equal, a match, or a fellow; (S, M, K;) as also ↓ taniynN; (K, TA [in the CK tiniyn];) an equal in age; (T, M;) an equal in intellect, or in weakness, or in strength, or in manliness, or manly virtue: (ISk, S:) or a companion: (M:) pl. A^atonaAnN. (T, M.) You say, fulaAnN tin~u fulaAnK [Such a one is the like, or equal, &c., of such a one]. (S.) And huwa sin~uhu and tin~uhu and Hitonuhu [He is his like, or equal, &c.]. (T.) And humaA tin~aAni They two are equals in intellect, or in weakness, or in strength, or in manliness, or manly virtue. (ISk, S.) And SibowapN A^atonaAnN [Boys that are like each other, or equals, &c.]. (T.) And humo A^asonaAnN A^atonaAnN They are equals in age. (IAar, T.) ― -b2- A boy stunted by disease, (Lth, T, M,) so that he does not attain to full growth; (Lth, T;) as also ↓ tan~N.
